   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">

   </h1>

       <td style="padding-left:0;">
        <a href="/wiki/Origins_of_the_Kingdom_of_Alba" title="Origins of the Kingdom of Alba">
         Established
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        9th century
        <small>
         (
         <a href="/wiki/National_myth" title="National myth">
          traditionally
         </a>
         843)
        </small>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedrow">
       <td style="width:1.0em;padding:0 0 0 0.6em;">
        •
       </td>
       <td style="padding-left:0;">
        <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">
         Union with England
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        1 May 1707
       </td>
      </tr>

        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        19 November 1998
       </td>

      <tr style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          a.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        Often shown abbreviated as "In Defens".
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          b.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Flower_of_Scotland" title="Flower of Scotland">
          Flower of Scotland
         </a>
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Scotland_the_Brave" title="Scotland the Brave">
          Scotland the Brave
         </a>
        </i>
        and
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Scots_Wha_Hae" title="Scots Wha Hae">
          Scots Wha Hae
         </a>
        </i>
        have been used in lieu of an official anthem (see
        <a href="/wiki/National_anthem_of_Scotland" title="National anthem of Scotland">
         National anthem of Scotland
        </a>
        ).
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          c.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        Both Scots and Scottish Gaelic are officially recognised as
        <a href="/wiki/Regional_language" title="Regional language">
         regional languages
        </a>
        under the
        <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">
         European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages
        </a>
        .
        <big>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
          <a href="#cite_note-10">
           [10]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </big>
        Under the
        <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Language_(Scotland)_Act_2005" title="Gaelic Language (Scotland) Act 2005">
         Gaelic Language (Scotland) Act 2005
        </a>
        , the
        <a href="/wiki/B%C3%B2rd_na_G%C3%A0idhlig" title="Bòrd na Gàidhlig">
         Bòrd na Gàidhlig
        </a>
        is tasked with securing Gaelic as an
        <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">
         official language
        </a>
        of Scotland that commands "equal respect" with English.
        <big>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
          <a href="#cite_note-11">
           [11]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </big>
        British Sign Language is also officially recognised in Scotland under the
        <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=British_Sign_Language_(Scotland)_Act_2015&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="British Sign Language (Scotland) Act 2015 (page does not exist)">
         British Sign Language (Scotland) Act 2015
        </a>
        .
        <big>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-British_Sign_Language_12-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-British_Sign_Language-12">
           [12]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </big>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          d.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        Historically, the use of "
        <a href="/wiki/Scotch_(adjective)" title="Scotch (adjective)">
         Scotch
        </a>
        " as an adjective comparable to "Scottish" or "Scots" was commonplace, particularly outside Scotland. Today, however, the term is used to describe
        <i>
         products
        </i>
        of Scotland (usually food or drink-related).
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          e.
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        The head of state of the United Kingdom is the monarch (currently Queen Elizabeth II, since 1952). Scotland has limited self-government within the United Kingdom as well as representation in the UK Parliament. It is also
        <a href="/wiki/Scotland_(European_Parliament_constituency)" title="Scotland (European Parliament constituency)">
         a UK electoral region
        </a>
        for the
        <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">
         European Parliament
        </a>
        . Certain executive and legislative powers have been devolved to, respectively, the
        <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">
         Scottish Government
        </a>
        and the
        <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">
         Scottish Parliament
        </a>
        at
        <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_Building" title="Scottish Parliament Building">
         Holyrood
        </a>
        in Edinburgh.
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr class="mergedbottomrow" style="font-size:85%;">
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        <span style="position: relative; top: 0.3em;">
         <sup>
          <big>
           f.
          </big>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;">
        .scot is not a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CcTLD" title="CcTLD">
         ccTLD
        </a>
        , but a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GTLD" title="GTLD">
         gTLD
        </a>
        , open to use by all people in Scotland and related to Scotland.
        <a href="/wiki/.uk" title=".uk">
         .uk
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">
         .eu
        </a>
        , as part of the
        <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
         United Kingdom
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
         European Union
        </a>
        , are also used.
        <a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-1" title="ISO 3166-1">
         ISO 3166-1
        </a>
        is
        <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">
         GB
        </a>
        , but
        <a href="/wiki/.gb" title=".gb">
         .gb
        </a>
        is unused.
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      <b>
       Scotland
      </b>
      (
      <span class="nowrap">
       <span class="IPA nopopups">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_English" title="Help:IPA for English">
         /
         <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
          <span title="/ˈ/ primary stress follows">
           ˈ
          </span>
          <span title="'s' in 'sigh'">
           s
          </span>
          <span title="'k' in 'kind'">
           k
          </span>
          <span title="/ɒ/ short 'o' in 'body'">
           ɒ
          </span>
          <span title="'t' in 'tie'">
           t
          </span>
          <span title="/./ syllable break">
           .
          </span>
          <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
           l
          </span>
          <span title="/ə/ 'a' in 'about'">
           ə
          </span>
          <span title="'n' in 'no'">
           n
          </span>
          <span title="'d' in 'dye'">
           d
          </span>
         </span>
         /
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
      ;
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">
       Scots
      </a>
      :
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">
        [ˈskɔt.lənd]
       </a>
      </span>
      ;
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic_language" title="Scottish Gaelic language">
       Scottish Gaelic
      </a>
      :
      <span lang="gd">
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Alba" title="Alba">
         Alba
        </a>
       </i>
      </span>
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Scottish_Gaelic" title="Help:IPA for Scottish Gaelic">
        [ˈal̪ˠapə]
       </a>
      </span>
      <small class="nowrap metadata">
       (
       <a href="/wiki/File:Alba-gd.ogg" title="File:Alba-gd.ogg">
        <img alt="" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="500" height="13" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/13px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/20px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Speaker_Icon.svg/26px-Speaker_Icon.svg.png 2x" width="13"/>
       </a>
       <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4f/Alba-gd.ogg" title="Alba-gd.ogg">
        listen
       </a>
       )
      </small>
      ) is a
      <a href="/wiki/Country" title="Country">
       country
      </a>
      that is
      <a href="/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Countries of the United Kingdom">
       part
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
       United Kingdom
      </a>
      and covers the northern third of the island of
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">
       Great Britain
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stats_1_13-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Stats_1-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Country_14-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Country-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It shares a border with
      <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">
       England
      </a>
      to the south, and is otherwise surrounded by the
      <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">
       Atlantic Ocean
      </a>
      , with the
      <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">
       North Sea
      </a>
      to the east and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Channel_(British_Isles)" title="North Channel (British Isles)">
       North Channel
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Irish_Sea" title="Irish Sea">
       Irish Sea
      </a>
      to the south-west. In addition to the mainland, the country is made up of more than 790 islands,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scottish_Executive_16-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Scottish_Executive-16">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      including the
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Isles" title="Northern Isles">
       Northern Isles
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Hebrides" title="Hebrides">
       Hebrides
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland" title="Kingdom of Scotland">
       Kingdom of Scotland
      </a>
      emerged as an independent sovereign state in the
      <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">
       Early Middle Ages
      </a>
      and continued to exist until 1707. By inheritance in 1603,
      <a href="/wiki/James_VI_and_I" title="James VI and I">
       James VI
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_monarchs" title="List of Scottish monarchs">
       King of Scots
      </a>
      , became
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_English_monarchs#House_of_Stuart" title="List of English monarchs">
       King of England
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_Ireland#Monarchs_of_Ireland" title="Monarchy of Ireland">
       King of Ireland
      </a>
      , thus forming a
      <a href="/wiki/Union_of_the_Crowns" title="Union of the Crowns">
       personal union of the three kingdoms
      </a>
      . Scotland subsequently entered into a
      <a href="/wiki/Political_union" title="Political union">
       political union
      </a>
      with the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">
       Kingdom of England
      </a>
      on 1 May 1707 to create the new
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">
       Kingdom of Great Britain
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keay_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Keay-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mackie_18-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mackie-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (The
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">
       Treaty of Union
      </a>
      was agreed in 1706 and enacted by the twin
      <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">
       Acts of Union 1707
      </a>
      , passed by the Parliaments of both kingdoms, despite popular opposition and anti-union riots in
      <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">
       Edinburgh
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">
       Glasgow
      </a>
      , and elsewhere).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1707_protests_19-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-1707_protests-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The union also created a new
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Great_Britain" title="Parliament of Great Britain">
       Parliament of Great Britain
      </a>
      , which succeeded both the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland" title="Parliament of Scotland">
       Parliament of Scotland
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_England" title="Parliament of England">
       Parliament of England
      </a>
      . (In 1801, Great Britain itself entered into a political union with the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland" title="Kingdom of Ireland">
       Kingdom of Ireland
      </a>
      to create the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">
       United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
      </a>
      ; the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Ireland" title="Parliament of Ireland">
       Parliament of Ireland
      </a>
      merging with that of Great Britain to form the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">
       Parliament of the United Kingdom
      </a>
      . Since the creation of the
      <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">
       Irish Free State
      </a>
      in 1922, the United Kingdom has comprised Great Britain and
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">
       Northern Ireland
      </a>
      ).
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">
       monarchy of the United Kingdom
      </a>
      continues to use a variety of styles, titles and other royal symbols of statehood specific to pre-union Scotland, including: the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Standard_of_Scotland" title="Royal Standard of Scotland">
       Royal Standard of Scotland
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_coat_of_arms_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom">
       Royal coat of arms
      </a>
      used in Scotland together with its associated
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Standard_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Royal Standard of the United Kingdom">
       Royal Standard
      </a>
      , royal titles including that of
      <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_Rothesay" title="Duke of Rothesay">
       Duke of Rothesay
      </a>
      , certain
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Officer_of_State" title="Great Officer of State">
       Great Officers of State
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Chivalric_order" title="Chivalric order">
       chivalric
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_Thistle" title="Order of the Thistle">
       Order of the Thistle
      </a>
      and, since 1999, reinstating a ceremonial role for the
      <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Scotland" title="Crown of Scotland">
       Crown of Scotland
      </a>
      after a 292-year hiatus.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        [21]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland's legal system has also remained separate from those of
      <a href="/wiki/English_law" title="English law">
       England and Wales
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_law" title="Northern Ireland law">
       Northern Ireland
      </a>
      , and Scotland constitutes a distinct jurisdiction in public and private law.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        [22]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The continued existence of
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_law" title="Scots law">
       legal
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">
       educational
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Scotland" title="Religion in Scotland">
       religious
      </a>
      and other institutions distinct from those in the remainder of the UK have all contributed to the continuation of Scottish culture and national identity since the 1707 union with England.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-administrative_control_23-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-administrative_control-23">
        [23]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Edinburgh, the country's capital and second-largest city, was the hub of the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Enlightenment" title="Scottish Enlightenment">
       Scottish Enlightenment
      </a>
      of the 18th century, which transformed Scotland into one of the commercial, intellectual, and industrial powerhouses of
      <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
       Europe
      </a>
      . Glasgow, Scotland's largest city,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        [24]
       </a>
      </sup>
      was once one of the world's leading industrial cities and now lies at the centre of the
      <a href="/wiki/Greater_Glasgow" title="Greater Glasgow">
       Greater Glasgow
      </a>
      conurbation. Other major
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_towns_and_cities_in_Scotland_by_population#Settlements" title="List of towns and cities in Scotland by population">
       urban areas
      </a>
      are
      <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen" title="Aberdeen">
       Aberdeen
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Dundee" title="Dundee">
       Dundee
      </a>
      . Scottish waters consist of a large sector of the North Atlantic and the North Sea,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        [25]
       </a>
      </sup>
      containing the largest
      <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">
       oil reserves
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
       European Union
      </a>
      . This has given
      <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen" title="Aberdeen">
       Aberdeen
      </a>
      , the third-largest city in Scotland, the title of Europe's oil capital.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        [26]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Following a
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_devolution_referendum,_1997" title="Scottish devolution referendum, 1997">
       referendum
      </a>
      in 1997, a
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">
       Scottish Parliament
      </a>
      was re-established, in the form of a
      <a href="/wiki/Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Devolution in the United Kingdom">
       devolved
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral_legislature" title="Unicameral legislature">
       unicameral legislature
      </a>
      comprising 129
      <a href="/wiki/Member_of_the_Scottish_Parliament" title="Member of the Scottish Parliament">
       members
      </a>
      , having authority over many areas of
      <a href="/wiki/Domestic_policy" title="Domestic policy">
       domestic policy
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_National_Party" title="Scottish National Party">
       Scottish National Party
      </a>
      , (SNP), which supports
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_independence" title="Scottish independence">
       Scottish independence
      </a>
      , won an overall majority in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_general_election,_2011" title="Scottish Parliament general election, 2011">
       2011 Scottish Parliament general election
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
       <a href="#cite_note-27">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and legislated for an
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_independence_referendum,_2014" title="Scottish independence referendum, 2014">
       independence referendum
      </a>
      which was held on 18 September 2014; a majority of 55% to 45% rejected independence on an 85%
      <a href="/wiki/Voter_turnout" title="Voter turnout">
       voter turnout
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-result_28-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bbc-result-28">
        [28]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">
       UK Conservative Party
      </a>
      won an overall majority in the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_2015" title="United Kingdom general election, 2015">
       2015 UK general election
      </a>
      and legislated for a
      <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum,_2016" title="United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016">
       referendum on the UK's membership of the European Union
      </a>
      which was held on 23 June 2016; within Scotland, a majority of 62% to 38% rejected
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_withdrawal_from_the_European_Union" title="United Kingdom withdrawal from the European Union">
       withdrawal from the EU
      </a>
      on a 67% voter turnout.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-EU-result_30-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bbc-EU-result-30">
        [30]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland is represented in the UK Parliament by 59
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(United_Kingdom)" title="Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)">
       MPs
      </a>
      and in the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">
       European Parliament
      </a>
      by 6
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Members_of_the_European_Parliament" title="Members of the European Parliament">
       MEPs
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ScotMEPs_31-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ScotMEPs-31">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland is also a member nation of the
      <a href="/wiki/British%E2%80%93Irish_Council" title="British–Irish Council">
       British–Irish Council
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/British%E2%80%93Irish_Parliamentary_Assembly" title="British–Irish Parliamentary Assembly">
       British–Irish Parliamentary Assembly
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     </div>
     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Scotland" title="History of Scotland">
       History of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
       Etymology
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Etymology_of_Scotland" title="Etymology of Scotland">
       Etymology of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      "Scotland" comes from
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Scoti" title="Scoti">
        Scoti
       </a>
      </i>
      , the Latin name for the
      <a href="/wiki/Gaels" title="Gaels">
       Gaels
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Late_Latin" title="Late Latin">
       Late Latin
      </a>
      word
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Scotia" title="Scotia">
        Scotia
       </a>
      </i>
      ("land of the Gaels") was initially used to refer to
      <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">
       Ireland
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        [33]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By the 11th century at the latest,
      <i>
       Scotia
      </i>
      was being used to refer to (Gaelic-speaking) Scotland north of the
      <a href="/wiki/River_Forth" title="River Forth">
       river Forth
      </a>
      , alongside
      <i>
       Albania
      </i>
      or
      <i>
       Albany
      </i>
      , both derived from the Gaelic
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Alba" title="Alba">
        Alba
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brewer_34-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Brewer-34">
        [34]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The use of the words
      <i>
       Scots
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       Scotland
      </i>
      to encompass all of what is now Scotland became common in the
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_in_the_Late_Middle_Ages" title="Scotland in the Late Middle Ages">
       Late Middle Ages
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keay_17-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Keay-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">
       Early history
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Scotland" title="Prehistoric Scotland">
       Prehistoric Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_prehistoric_Scotland" title="Timeline of prehistoric Scotland">
       Timeline of prehistoric Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Repeated glaciations, which covered the entire land mass of modern Scotland, destroyed any traces of human habitation that may have existed before the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mesolithic_period" title="Mesolithic period">
       Mesolithic period
      </a>
      . It is believed the first post-glacial groups of
      <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">
       hunter-gatherers
      </a>
      arrived in Scotland around 12,800 years ago, as the ice sheet retreated after the
      <a href="/wiki/Last_glacial_period" title="Last glacial period">
       last glaciation
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        [35]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
       <a href="#cite_note-36">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Skara_Brae_12.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Skara_Brae_12.jpg/220px-Skara_Brae_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Skara_Brae_12.jpg/330px-Skara_Brae_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Skara_Brae_12.jpg/440px-Skara_Brae_12.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Skara_Brae_12.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scara_Brae" title="Scara Brae">
         Scara Brae
        </a>
        . A
        <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
         Neolithic
        </a>
        settlement, located on the west coast of
        <a href="/wiki/Mainland,_Orkney" title="Mainland, Orkney">
         Mainland, Orkney
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The groups of settlers began building the first known permanent houses on Scottish soil around 9,500 years ago, and the first villages around 6,000 years ago. The well-preserved village of
      <a href="/wiki/Skara_Brae" title="Skara Brae">
       Skara Brae
      </a>
      on the mainland of
      <a href="/wiki/Orkney" title="Orkney">
       Orkney
      </a>
      dates from this period.
      <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">
       Neolithic
      </a>
      habitation, burial and ritual sites are particularly common and well preserved in the
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Isles" title="Northern Isles">
       Northern Isles
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Isles" title="Western Isles">
       Western Isles
      </a>
      , where a lack of trees led to most structures being built of local stone.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
       <a href="#cite_note-37">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The 2009 discovery in Scotland of a 4000-year-old tomb with burial treasures at
      <a href="/wiki/Forteviot" title="Forteviot">
       Forteviot
      </a>
      , near
      <a href="/wiki/Perth,_Scotland" title="Perth, Scotland">
       Perth
      </a>
      , the capital of a
      <a href="/wiki/Picts" title="Picts">
       Pictish
      </a>
      Kingdom in the 8th and 9th centuries AD, is unrivalled anywhere in Britain. It contains the remains of an
      <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Scotland" title="Prehistoric Scotland">
       early Bronze Age
      </a>
      ruler laid out on white
      <a href="/wiki/Quartz" title="Quartz">
       quartz
      </a>
      pebbles and birch bark. It was also discovered for the first time that early Bronze Age people placed flowers in their graves.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        [38]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TFDB_39-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TFDB-39">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Scotland may have been part of a Late Bronze Age maritime trading culture called the
      <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Bronze_Age" title="Atlantic Bronze Age">
       Atlantic Bronze Age
      </a>
      , which included other
      <a href="/wiki/Celtic_nations" title="Celtic nations">
       Celtic nations
      </a>
      , and the areas that became England, France, Spain, and Portugal.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koch_40-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Koch-40">
        [40]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koch2009_41-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Koch2009-41">
        [41]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the winter of 1850, a severe storm hit Scotland, causing widespread damage and over 200 deaths.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bryson2010_44-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bryson2010-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the Bay of Skaill, the storm stripped the earth from a large irregular knoll, known as "Skerrabra". When the storm cleared, local villagers found the outline of a village, consisting of a number of small houses without roofs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bryson2010_44-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-bryson2010-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OSB_45-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-OSB-45">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      William Watt of Skaill, the local
      <a href="/wiki/Laird" title="Laird">
       laird
      </a>
      , began an amateur excavation of the site, but after uncovering four houses, the work was abandoned in 1868.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OSB_45-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-OSB-45">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The site remained undisturbed until 1913, when during a single weekend the site was plundered by a party with shovels who took away an unknown quantity of artefacts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bryson2010_44-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-bryson2010-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1924, another storm swept away part of one of the houses and it was determined the site should be made secure and more seriously investigated.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bryson2010_44-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-bryson2010-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The job was given to
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh" title="University of Edinburgh">
       University of Edinburgh
      </a>
      's Professor
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vere_Gordon_Childe" title="Vere Gordon Childe">
       Vere Gordon Childe
      </a>
      who travelled to Skara Brae for the first time in mid-1927.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bryson2010_44-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-bryson2010-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Roman_influence">
       Roman influence
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_during_the_Roman_Empire" title="Scotland during the Roman Empire">
       Scotland during the Roman Empire
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2433" data-file-width="1904" height="281" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG/220px-Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG/330px-Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG/440px-Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bridgeness_slab_detail.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Tablet found at
        <a href="/wiki/Bo%27ness" title="Bo'ness">
         Bo'ness
        </a>
        dated ca.
        <span class="smallcaps">
         <span style="font-variant: small-caps; text-transform: lowercase;">
          AD
         </span>
        </span>
        142 depicting Roman cavalryman trampling
        <a href="/wiki/Picts" title="Picts">
         Picts
        </a>
        . Now at the
        <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Scotland" title="National Museum of Scotland">
         NMS
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The written
      <a href="/wiki/Protohistory" title="Protohistory">
       protohistory
      </a>
      of Scotland began with the arrival of the
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
       Roman Empire
      </a>
      in southern and central Great Britain, when the Romans occupied what is now England and Wales, administering it as a province called
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">
        Britannia
       </a>
      </i>
      . Roman invasions and occupations of southern Scotland were a series of brief interludes.
     </p>
     <p>
      According to the Roman historian
      <a href="/wiki/Tacitus" title="Tacitus">
       Tacitus
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Caledonians" title="Caledonians">
       Caledonians
      </a>
      "turned to armed resistance on a large scale", attacking Roman forts and skirmishing with their
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Legion" title="Roman Legion">
       legions
      </a>
      . In a surprise night-attack, the Caledonians very nearly wiped out the whole
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/9th_Legion" title="9th Legion">
       9th Legion
      </a>
      until it was saved by Agricola's cavalry.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Romans_in_Scotland_46-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-The_Romans_in_Scotland-46">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In AD 83–84, the General
      <a href="/wiki/Gnaeus_Julius_Agricola" title="Gnaeus Julius Agricola">
       Gnaeus Julius Agricola
      </a>
      defeated the Caledonians at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mons_Graupius" title="Battle of Mons Graupius">
       Battle of Mons Graupius
      </a>
      . Tacitus wrote that, before the battle, the Caledonian leader,
      <a href="/wiki/Calgacus" title="Calgacus">
       Calgacus
      </a>
      , gave a rousing speech in which he called his people the "last of the free" and accused the Romans of "making the world a desert and calling it peace" (freely translated).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Romans_in_Scotland_46-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-The_Romans_in_Scotland-46">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the Roman victory, Roman forts were briefly set along the
      <a href="/wiki/Gask_Ridge" title="Gask Ridge">
       Gask Ridge
      </a>
      close to the
      <a href="/wiki/Highland_Boundary_Fault" title="Highland Boundary Fault">
       Highland line
      </a>
      (only
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cawdor_(Roman_Fort)" title="Cawdor (Roman Fort)">
       Cawdor
      </a>
      near
      <a href="/wiki/Inverness" title="Inverness">
       Inverness
      </a>
      is known to have been constructed beyond that line). Three years after the battle, the Roman armies had withdrawn to the
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Uplands" title="Southern Uplands">
       Southern Uplands
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        [47]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Romans erected
      <a href="/wiki/Hadrian%27s_Wall" title="Hadrian's Wall">
       Hadrian's Wall
      </a>
      to control tribes on both sides of the wall
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-snyder_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-snyder-48">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      so the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Limes_Britannicus" title="Limes Britannicus">
        Limes Britannicus
       </a>
      </i>
      became the northern border of the Roman Empire; although the army held the
      <a href="/wiki/Antonine_Wall" title="Antonine Wall">
       Antonine Wall
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Lowlands" title="Central Lowlands">
       Central Lowlands
      </a>
      for two short periods – the last during the reign of Emperor
      <a href="/wiki/Septimius_Severus" title="Septimius Severus">
       Septimius Severus
      </a>
      from 208 until 210.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        [49]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Roman military occupation of a significant part of what is now northern Scotland lasted only about 40 years; although their influence on the southern section of the country, occupied by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brython" title="Brython">
       Brythonic
      </a>
      tribes such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Votadini" title="Votadini">
       Votadini
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Damnonii" title="Damnonii">
       Damnonii
      </a>
      , would still have been considerable between the first and fifth centuries. The
      <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">
       Welsh
      </a>
      term
      <a href="/wiki/Hen_Ogledd" title="Hen Ogledd">
       Hen Ogledd
      </a>
      ("Old North") is used by scholars to describe what is now the North of England and the South of Scotland during its habitation by
      <a href="/wiki/Common_Brittonic" title="Common Brittonic">
       Brittonic
      </a>
      -speaking people around AD 500 to 800.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-snyder_48-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-snyder-48">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to writings from the 9th and 10th centuries, the
      <a href="/wiki/Gaels" title="Gaels">
       Gaelic
      </a>
      kingdom of
      <a href="/wiki/D%C3%A1l_Riata" title="Dál Riata">
       Dál Riata
      </a>
      was founded in the 6th century in western Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
       <a href="#cite_note-50">
        [50]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        [51]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The 'traditional' view is that settlers from Ireland founded the kingdom, bringing Gaelic language and culture with them. However, recently some archaeologists have argued against this view, saying there is no archaeological or placename evidence for a migration or a takeover by a small group of elites.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ewancampbell_52-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ewancampbell-52">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">
       Middle Ages
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_in_the_Early_Middle_Ages" title="Scotland in the Early Middle Ages">
       Scotland in the Early Middle Ages
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_in_the_High_Middle_Ages" title="Scotland in the High Middle Ages">
       Scotland in the High Middle Ages
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_in_the_Late_Middle_Ages" title="Scotland in the Late Middle Ages">
       Scotland in the Late Middle Ages
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Serpent_stone.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="2304" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Serpent_stone.JPG/170px-Serpent_stone.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Serpent_stone.JPG/255px-Serpent_stone.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Serpent_stone.JPG/340px-Serpent_stone.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Serpent_stone.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The class I
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pictish_stones" title="Pictish stones">
         Pictish stone
        </a>
        at
        <a href="/wiki/Aberlemno_Sculptured_Stones#Aberlemno_1" title="Aberlemno Sculptured Stones">
         Aberlemno
        </a>
        known as Aberlemno 1 or the Serpent Stone.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Picts" title="Kingdom of the Picts">
       Kingdom of the Picts
      </a>
      (based in
      <a href="/wiki/Fortriu" title="Fortriu">
       Fortriu
      </a>
      by the 6th century) was the state that eventually became known as "Alba" or "Scotland". The development of "Pictland", according to the historical model developed by
      <a href="/wiki/Peter_Heather" title="Peter Heather">
       Peter Heather
      </a>
      , was a natural response to Roman imperialism.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
       <a href="#cite_note-53">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Another view places emphasis on the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dun_Nechtain" title="Battle of Dun Nechtain">
       Battle of Dun Nechtain
      </a>
      , and the reign of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bridei_III_of_the_Picts" title="Bridei III of the Picts">
       Bridei m. Beli
      </a>
      (671–693), with another period of consolidation in the reign of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%93engus_I_of_the_Picts" title="Óengus I of the Picts">
       Óengus mac Fergusa
      </a>
      (732–761).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Kingdom of the Picts as it was in the early 8th century, when
      <a href="/wiki/Bede" title="Bede">
       Bede
      </a>
      was writing, was largely the same as the kingdom of the Scots in the reign of
      <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Scotland" title="Alexander I of Scotland">
       Alexander I
      </a>
      (1107–1124). However, by the tenth century, the Pictish kingdom was dominated by what we can recognise as Gaelic culture, and had developed a traditional story of an Irish conquest around the ancestor of the contemporary royal dynasty,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kenneth_I_of_Scotland" title="Kenneth I of Scotland">
       Cináed mac Ailpín
      </a>
      (Kenneth MacAlpin).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lynch_359_55-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Lynch_359-55">
        [55]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      From a base of territory in eastern Scotland north of the
      <a href="/wiki/River_Forth" title="River Forth">
       River Forth
      </a>
      and south of the
      <a href="/wiki/River_Oykel" title="River Oykel">
       River Oykel
      </a>
      , the kingdom acquired control of the lands lying to the north and south. By the 12th century, the kings of Alba had added to their territories the
      <a href="/wiki/Old_English" title="Old English">
       English
      </a>
      -speaking land in the south-east and attained overlordship of
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">
       Gaelic
      </a>
      -speaking
      <a href="/wiki/Galloway" title="Galloway">
       Galloway
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Old_Norse" title="Old Norse">
       Norse
      </a>
      -speaking
      <a href="/wiki/Caithness" title="Caithness">
       Caithness
      </a>
      ; by the end of the 13th century, the kingdom had assumed approximately its modern borders. However, processes of cultural and economic change beginning in the 12th century ensured Scotland looked very different in the later Middle Ages.
     </p>
     <p>
      The push for this change was the reign of
      <a href="/wiki/David_I_of_Scotland" title="David I of Scotland">
       David I
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Davidian_Revolution" title="Davidian Revolution">
       Davidian Revolution
      </a>
      . Feudalism, government reorganisation and the first legally recognised towns (called
      <a href="/wiki/Burgh" title="Burgh">
       burghs
      </a>
      ) began in this period. These institutions and the immigration of French and Anglo-French knights and churchmen facilitated cultural osmosis, whereby the culture and language of the low-lying and coastal parts of the kingdom's original territory in the east became, like the newly acquired south-east, English-speaking, while the rest of the country retained the Gaelic language, apart from the Northern Isles of Orkney and Shetland, which remained under Norse rule until 1468.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        [58]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barrow_59-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Barrow-59">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        [60]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Scottish state entered a largely successful and stable period between the 12th and 14th centuries, there was relative peace with England, trade and educational links were well developed with the Continent and at the height of this cultural flowering
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Duns_Scotus" title="John Duns Scotus">
       John Duns Scotus
      </a>
      was one of Europe's most important and influential philosophers.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1397" data-file-width="894" height="266" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg/170px-Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg/255px-Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg/340px-Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wfm_wallace_monument_cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Wallace_Monument" title="Wallace Monument">
         Wallace Monument
        </a>
        commemorates
        <a href="/wiki/William_Wallace" title="William Wallace">
         William Wallace
        </a>
        , the 13th-century Scottish hero.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The death of
      <a href="/wiki/Alexander_III_of_Scotland" title="Alexander III of Scotland">
       Alexander III
      </a>
      in March 1286, followed by that of his granddaughter
      <a href="/wiki/Margaret,_Maid_of_Norway" title="Margaret, Maid of Norway">
       Margaret, Maid of Norway
      </a>
      , broke the centuries-old succession line of Scotland's kings and shattered the 200-year golden age that began with David I.
      <a href="/wiki/Edward_I_of_England" title="Edward I of England">
       Edward I of England
      </a>
      was asked to arbitrate between claimants for the Scottish crown, and he organised a process known as the
      <a href="/wiki/Competitors_for_the_Crown_of_Scotland" title="Competitors for the Crown of Scotland">
       Great Cause
      </a>
      to identify the most legitimate claimant.
      <a href="/wiki/John_Balliol" title="John Balliol">
       John Balliol
      </a>
      was pronounced king in the Great Hall of
      <a href="/wiki/Berwick_Castle" title="Berwick Castle">
       Berwick Castle
      </a>
      on 17 November 1292 and inaugurated at
      <a href="/wiki/Scone,_Perth_and_Kinross" title="Scone, Perth and Kinross">
       Scone
      </a>
      on 30 November,
      <a href="/wiki/St._Andrew%27s_Day" title="St. Andrew's Day">
       St. Andrew's Day
      </a>
      . Edward I, who had coerced recognition as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lord_Paramount_of_Scotland" title="Lord Paramount of Scotland">
       Lord Paramount of Scotland
      </a>
      , the feudal superior of the realm, steadily undermined John's authority.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        [61]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1294, Balliol and other Scottish lords refused Edward's demands to serve in his army against the French. Instead the Scottish parliament sent envoys to France to negotiate an alliance. Scotland and France sealed a treaty on 23 October 1295, known as the
      <a href="/wiki/Auld_Alliance" title="Auld Alliance">
       Auld Alliance
      </a>
      (1295–1560). War ensued and King John was deposed by Edward who took personal control of Scotland.
      <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Moray" title="Andrew Moray">
       Andrew Moray
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/William_Wallace" title="William Wallace">
       William Wallace
      </a>
      initially emerged as the principal leaders of the resistance to English rule in what became known as the
      <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_Scottish_Independence" title="Wars of Scottish Independence">
       Wars of Scottish Independence
      </a>
      (1296–1328).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The nature of the struggle changed significantly when
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_the_Bruce" title="Robert the Bruce">
       Robert the Bruce, Earl of Carrick
      </a>
      , killed his rival
      <a href="/wiki/John_III_Comyn,_Lord_of_Badenoch" title="John III Comyn, Lord of Badenoch">
       John Comyn
      </a>
      on 10 February 1306 at
      <a href="/wiki/Greyfriars_Kirk" title="Greyfriars Kirk">
       Greyfriars Kirk
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Dumfries" title="Dumfries">
       Dumfries
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
       <a href="#cite_note-63">
        [63]
       </a>
      </sup>
      He was crowned king (as Robert I) less than seven weeks later. Robert I battled to restore Scottish Independence as King for over 20 years, beginning by winning Scotland back from the Norman English invaders piece by piece. Victory at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bannockburn" title="Battle of Bannockburn">
       Battle of Bannockburn
      </a>
      in 1314 proved the Scots had regained control of their kingdom. In 1315,
      <a href="/wiki/Edward_Bruce" title="Edward Bruce">
       Edward Bruce
      </a>
      , brother of the King, was briefly appointed
      <a href="/wiki/High_King_of_Ireland" title="High King of Ireland">
       High King of Ireland
      </a>
      during an ultimately unsuccessful Scottish invasion of Ireland aimed at strengthening Scotland's position in its wars against England. In 1320 the world's first documented declaration of independence, the
      <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Arbroath" title="Declaration of Arbroath">
       Declaration of Arbroath
      </a>
      , won the support of
      <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXII" title="Pope John XXII">
       Pope John XXII
      </a>
      , leading to the legal recognition of Scottish sovereignty by the English Crown.
     </p>
     <p>
      However, war with England continued for several decades after the death of Bruce. A civil war between the Bruce dynasty and their long-term Comyn-Balliol rivals lasted until the middle of the 14th century. Although the Bruce dynasty was successful,
      <a href="/wiki/David_II_of_Scotland" title="David II of Scotland">
       David II's
      </a>
      lack of an heir allowed his half-nephew
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_II_of_Scotland" title="Robert II of Scotland">
       Robert II
      </a>
      to come to the throne and establish the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stewart_Dynasty" title="Stewart Dynasty">
       Stewart Dynasty
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barrow_59-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Barrow-59">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grant_64-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grant-64">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Stewarts ruled Scotland for the remainder of the
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
       Middle Ages
      </a>
      . The country they ruled experienced greater prosperity from the end of the 14th century through the Scottish Renaissance to the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Reformation" title="Scottish Reformation">
       Reformation
      </a>
      . This was despite continual warfare with England, the increasing division between
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">
       Highlands
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Lowlands" title="Scottish Lowlands">
       Lowlands
      </a>
      , and a large number of royal minorities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grant_64-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Grant-64">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
       <a href="#cite_note-65">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      This period was the height of the Franco-Scottish alliance. The Scots Guard – la
      <a href="/wiki/Garde_%C3%89cossaise" title="Garde Écossaise">
       Garde Écossaise
      </a>
      – was founded in 1418 by
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_VII_of_France" title="Charles VII of France">
       Charles VII of France
      </a>
      . The Scots soldiers of the Garde Écossaise fought alongside
      <a href="/wiki/Joan_of_Arc" title="Joan of Arc">
       Joan of Arc
      </a>
      against England during the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hundred_Years_War" title="Hundred Years War">
       Hundred Years War
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        [66]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In March 1421, a Franco-Scots force under
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Stewart,_2nd_Earl_of_Buchan" title="John Stewart, 2nd Earl of Buchan">
       John Stewart, 2nd Earl of Buchan
      </a>
      , and Gilbert de Lafayette, defeated a larger English army at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Baug%C3%A9" title="Battle of Baugé">
       Battle of Baugé
      </a>
      . Three years later, at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Verneuil" title="Battle of Verneuil">
       Battle of Verneuil
      </a>
      , the French and Scots lost around 7000 men.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
       <a href="#cite_note-67">
        [67]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Scottish intervention contributed to France's victory in the war.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_era">
       Early modern era
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scotland_in_the_Early_Modern_Era" title="Scotland in the Early Modern Era">
       Scotland in the Early Modern Era
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_(1618-1620).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="889" data-file-width="526" height="287" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_%281618-1620%29.jpg/170px-Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_%281618-1620%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_%281618-1620%29.jpg/255px-Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_%281618-1620%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_%281618-1620%29.jpg/340px-Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_%281618-1620%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_King_James_I_%26_VI_(1618-1620).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/James_VI_and_I" title="James VI and I">
         James VI
        </a>
        succeeded to the English and Irish thrones in 1603.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1502,
      <a href="/wiki/James_IV_of_Scotland" title="James IV of Scotland">
       James IV of Scotland
      </a>
      signed the
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Perpetual_Peace" title="Treaty of Perpetual Peace">
       Treaty of Perpetual Peace
      </a>
      with
      <a href="/wiki/Henry_VII_of_England" title="Henry VII of England">
       Henry VII of England
      </a>
      . He also married Henry's daughter,
      <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Tudor" title="Margaret Tudor">
       Margaret Tudor
      </a>
      , setting the stage for the
      <a href="/wiki/Union_of_the_Crowns" title="Union of the Crowns">
       Union of the Crowns
      </a>
      . For Henry, the marriage into one of Europe's most established monarchies gave legitimacy to the new Tudor royal line.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        [68]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A decade later, James made the fateful decision to invade England in support of France under the terms of the
      <a href="/wiki/Auld_Alliance" title="Auld Alliance">
       Auld Alliance
      </a>
      . He was the last British monarch to die in battle, at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Flodden" title="Battle of Flodden">
       Battle of Flodden
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
       <a href="#cite_note-69">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Within a generation the Auld Alliance was ended by the
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Edinburgh" title="Treaty of Edinburgh">
       Treaty of Edinburgh
      </a>
      . France agreed to withdraw all land and naval forces. In the same year, 1560,
      <a href="/wiki/John_Knox" title="John Knox">
       John Knox
      </a>
      realised his goal of seeing Scotland become a Protestant nation and the Scottish parliament revoke papal authority in Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
       <a href="#cite_note-70">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Mary,_Queen_of_Scots" title="Mary, Queen of Scots">
       Mary, Queen of Scots
      </a>
      , a Catholic and former queen of France, was forced to abdicate in 1567.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
       <a href="#cite_note-71">
        [71]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1603,
      <a href="/wiki/James_VI_and_I" title="James VI and I">
       James VI, King of Scots
      </a>
      inherited the thrones of the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">
       Kingdom of England
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland" title="Kingdom of Ireland">
       Kingdom of Ireland
      </a>
      , and became King James I of England and Ireland, and left
      <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">
       Edinburgh
      </a>
      for London.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With the exception of a short period under
      <a href="/wiki/The_Protectorate" title="The Protectorate">
       the Protectorate
      </a>
      , Scotland remained a separate state, but there was considerable conflict between the crown and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Covenanters" title="Covenanters">
       Covenanters
      </a>
      over the form of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterian_church_governance" title="Presbyterian church governance">
       church government
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">
       Glorious Revolution
      </a>
      of 1688–89 saw the overthrow of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_James_II_of_England" title="King James II of England">
       King James VII of Scotland and II of England
      </a>
      by the English Parliament in favour of
      <a href="/wiki/William_and_Mary" title="William and Mary">
       William and Mary
      </a>
      . As late as the 1690s, Scotland experienced famine, which reduced the population of parts of the country by at least 20 per cent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        [73]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1698, the Scots attempted an ambitious project to secure a trading colony on the
      <a href="/wiki/Isthmus_of_Panama" title="Isthmus of Panama">
       Isthmus of Panama
      </a>
      . Almost every Scottish landowner who had money to spare is said to have invested in the
      <a href="/wiki/Darien_scheme" title="Darien scheme">
       Darien scheme
      </a>
      . Its failure bankrupted these landowners, but not the burghs. Nevertheless, the nobles' bankruptcy, along with the threat of an English invasion, played a leading role in convincing the Scots elite to back a union with England.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        [74]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        [75]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On 22 July 1706, the
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">
       Treaty of Union
      </a>
      was agreed between representatives of the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland" title="Parliament of Scotland">
       Scots Parliament
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_England" title="Parliament of England">
       Parliament of England
      </a>
      and the following year twin
      <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">
       Acts of Union
      </a>
      were passed by both parliaments to create the united
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">
       Kingdom of Great Britain
      </a>
      with effect from 1 May 1707.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mackie_18-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mackie-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="18th_century">
       18th century
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="892" data-file-width="1498" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg/220px-The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg/330px-The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg/440px-The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Battle_of_Culloden.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        David Morier's depiction of the
        <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Culloden" title="Battle of Culloden">
         Battle of Culloden
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      With trade tariffs with England now abolished, trade blossomed, especially with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colonial_America" title="Colonial America">
       Colonial America
      </a>
      . The clippers belonging to the
      <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">
       Glasgow
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Tobacco_Lords" title="Tobacco Lords">
       Tobacco Lords
      </a>
      were the fastest ships on the route to Virginia. Until the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_War_of_Independence" title="American War of Independence">
       American War of Independence
      </a>
      in 1776, Glasgow was the world's premier tobacco port, dominating world trade.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The disparity between the wealth of the merchant classes of the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Lowlands" title="Scottish Lowlands">
       Scottish Lowlands
      </a>
      and the ancient clans of the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">
       Scottish Highlands
      </a>
      grew, amplifying centuries of division.
     </p>
     <p>
      The deposed
      <a href="/wiki/Jacobitism" title="Jacobitism">
       Jacobite Stuart
      </a>
      claimants had remained popular in the Highlands and north-east, particularly amongst non-
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterian" title="Presbyterian">
       Presbyterians
      </a>
      , including Roman Catholics and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Episcopalian_Protestants" title="Episcopalian Protestants">
       Episcopalian Protestants
      </a>
      . However, two major
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jacobite_Rising" title="Jacobite Rising">
       Jacobite Risings
      </a>
      launched in 1715 and 1745 failed to remove the
      <a href="/wiki/House_of_Hanover" title="House of Hanover">
       House of Hanover
      </a>
      from the British throne. The threat of the Jacobite movement to the United Kingdom and its monarchs effectively ended at the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Culloden" title="Battle of Culloden">
       Battle of Culloden
      </a>
      , Great Britain's last
      <a href="/wiki/Pitched_battle" title="Pitched battle">
       pitched battle
      </a>
      . This defeat paved the way for large-scale removals of the indigenous populations of the Highlands and Islands, known as the
      <a href="/wiki/Highland_Clearances" title="Highland Clearances">
       Highland Clearances
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Enlightenment" title="Scottish Enlightenment">
       Scottish Enlightenment
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">
       Industrial Revolution
      </a>
      made Scotland into an intellectual, commercial and industrial powerhouse
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      –so much so
      <a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">
       Voltaire
      </a>
      said "We look to Scotland for all our ideas of civilisation."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        [78]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With the demise of Jacobitism and the advent of the Union, thousands of Scots, mainly Lowlanders, took up numerous positions of power in politics, civil service, the army and navy, trade, economics, colonial enterprises and other areas across the nascent
      <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">
       British Empire
      </a>
      . Historian Neil Davidson notes "after 1746 there was an entirely new level of participation by Scots in political life, particularly outside Scotland." Davidson also states "far from being 'peripheral' to the British economy, Scotland – or more precisely, the Lowlands – lay at its core."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
       <a href="#cite_note-79">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="19th_century">
       19th century
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_in_the_modern_era" title="Scotland in the modern era">
       Scotland in the modern era
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_(1881).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1189" data-file-width="2000" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_%281881%29.jpg/220px-John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_%281881%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_%281881%29.jpg/330px-John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_%281881%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_%281881%29.jpg/440px-John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_%281881%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_Atkinson_Grimshaw_-_Shipping_on_the_Clyde_(1881).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <i>
         Shipping on the Clyde
        </i>
        , by
        <a href="/wiki/John_Atkinson_Grimshaw" title="John Atkinson Grimshaw">
         John Atkinson Grimshaw
        </a>
        , 1881
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Reform_Act_1832" title="Scottish Reform Act 1832">
       Scottish Reform Act 1832
      </a>
      increased the number of Scottish MPs and widened the franchise to include more of the middle classes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Devine.26Finlay1996pp64-5_80-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Devine.26Finlay1996pp64-5-80">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
      From the mid-century there were increasing calls for Home Rule for Scotland and the post of
      <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Scotland" title="Secretary of State for Scotland">
       Secretary of State for Scotland
      </a>
      was revived.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Towards the end of the century Prime Ministers of Scottish descent included
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_E._Gladstone" title="William E. Gladstone">
       William E. Gladstone
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Quinault2007_82-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Quinault2007-82">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Archibald_Primrose,_5th_Earl_of_Rosebery" title="Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery">
       the Earl of Rosebery
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the later 19th century the growing importance of the working classes was marked by
      <a href="/wiki/Keir_Hardie" title="Keir Hardie">
       Keir Hardie
      </a>
      's success in the
      <a href="/wiki/Mid_Lanarkshire_by-election,_1888" title="Mid Lanarkshire by-election, 1888">
       Mid Lanarkshire by-election, 1888
      </a>
      , leading to the foundation of the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Labour_Party_(1888)" title="Scottish Labour Party (1888)">
       Scottish Labour Party
      </a>
      , which was absorbed into the
      <a href="/wiki/Independent_Labour_Party" title="Independent Labour Party">
       Independent Labour Party
      </a>
      in 1895, with Hardie as its first leader.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Glasgow became one of the largest cities in the world, and known as "the Second City of the Empire" after London.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After 1860 the Clydeside shipyards specialised in steamships made of iron (after 1870, made of steel), which rapidly replaced the wooden sailing vessels of both the merchant fleets and the battle fleets of the world. It became the world's pre-eminent shipbuilding centre.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shields1949_86-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Shields1949-86">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The industrial developments, while they brought work and wealth, were so rapid that housing, town-planning, and provision for public health did not keep pace with them, and for a time living conditions in some of the towns and cities were notoriously bad, with overcrowding, high infant mortality, and growing rates of tuberculosis.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="1649" height="206" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg/170px-Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg/255px-Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg/340px-Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sir_Henry_Raeburn_-_Portrait_of_Sir_Walter_Scott.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">
         Walter Scott
        </a>
        , whose
        <a href="/wiki/Waverley_Novels" title="Waverley Novels">
         Waverley Novels
        </a>
        helped define Scottish identity in the 19th century.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      While the Scottish Enlightenment is traditionally considered to have concluded toward the end of the 18th century,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Magnusson_88-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Magnusson-88">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
      disproportionately large Scottish contributions to British science and letters continued for another 50 years or more, thanks to such figures as the physicists
      <a href="/wiki/James_Clerk_Maxwell" title="James Clerk Maxwell">
       James Clerk Maxwell
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/William_Thomson,_1st_Baron_Kelvin" title="William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin">
       Lord Kelvin
      </a>
      , and the engineers and inventors
      <a href="/wiki/James_Watt" title="James Watt">
       James Watt
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/William_Murdoch" title="William Murdoch">
       William Murdoch
      </a>
