      , whose work was critical to the technological developments of the Industrial Revolution throughout Britain.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In literature the most successful figure of the mid-19th century was
      <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">
       Walter Scott
      </a>
      . His first prose work,
      <a href="/wiki/Waverley_(novel)" title="Waverley (novel)">
       Waverley
      </a>
      in 1814, is often called the first historical novel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
       <a href="#cite_note-90">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It launched a highly successful career that probably more than any other helped define and popularise Scottish cultural identity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the late 19th century, a number of Scottish-born authors achieved international reputations, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson" title="Robert Louis Stevenson">
       Robert Louis Stevenson
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle">
       Arthur Conan Doyle
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/J._M._Barrie" title="J. M. Barrie">
       J. M. Barrie
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/George_MacDonald" title="George MacDonald">
       George MacDonald
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
       <a href="#cite_note-92">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland also played a major part in the development of art and architecture. The
      <a href="/wiki/Glasgow_School" title="Glasgow School">
       Glasgow School
      </a>
      , which developed in the late 19th century, and flourished in the early 20th century, produced a distinctive blend of influences including the
      <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Revival" title="Celtic Revival">
       Celtic Revival
      </a>
      the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arts_and_Crafts_Movement" title="Arts and Crafts Movement">
       Arts and Crafts Movement
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japonisme" title="Japonisme">
       Japonisme
      </a>
      , which found favour throughout the
      <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">
       modern art
      </a>
      world of continental Europe and helped define the
      <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">
       Art Nouveau
      </a>
      style. Proponents included architect and artist
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_Rennie_Mackintosh" title="Charles Rennie Mackintosh">
       Charles Rennie Mackintosh
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      This period saw a process of rehabilitation for Highland culture. In the 1820s, as part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">
       Romantic revival
      </a>
      , tartan and the kilt were adopted by members of the social elite, not just in Scotland, but across Europe,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sievers2007_95-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sievers2007-95">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
      prompted by the popularity of Macpherson's
      <a href="/wiki/Ossian" title="Ossian">
       Ossian
      </a>
      cycle
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and then Walter Scott's Waverley novels.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the Highlands remained very poor and traditional.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The desire to improve agriculture and profits led to the
      <a href="/wiki/Highland_Clearances" title="Highland Clearances">
       Highland Clearances
      </a>
      , in which much of the population of the Highlands suffered forced displacement as lands were enclosed, principally so that they could be used for sheep farming. The clearances followed patterns of agricultural change throughout Britain, but were particularly notorious as a result of the late timing, the lack of legal protection for year-by-year tenants under
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_law" title="Scots law">
       Scots law
      </a>
      , the abruptness of the change from the traditional clan system, and the brutality of many evictions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
       <a href="#cite_note-100">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
      One result was a continuous exodus from the land—to the cities, or further afield to England, Canada, America or Australia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
       <a href="#cite_note-101">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The population of Scotland grew steadily in the 19th century, from 1,608,000 in the census of 1801 to 2,889,000 in 1851 and 4,472,000 in 1901.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
       <a href="#cite_note-102">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even with the development of industry there were not enough good jobs. As a result, during the period 1841–1931, about 2 million Scots migrated to North America and Australia, and another 750,000 Scots relocated to England.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Huston.26Knox2001pxxxii_103-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Huston.26Knox2001pxxxii-103">
        [103]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1197" data-file-width="2606" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg/350px-Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg/525px-Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg/700px-Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg 2x" width="350"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Disruption_forming_Free_Kirk.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The Disruption Assembly; painted by
        <a href="/wiki/David_Octavius_Hill" title="David Octavius Hill">
         David Octavius Hill
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      After prolonged years of struggle in the Kirk, in 1834 the Evangelicals gained control of the
      <a href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_Church_of_Scotland" title="General Assembly of the Church of Scotland">
       General Assembly
      </a>
      and passed the Veto Act, which allowed congregations to reject unwanted "intrusive" presentations to livings by patrons. The following "Ten Years' Conflict" of legal and political wrangling ended in defeat for the non-intrusionists in the civil courts. The result was a schism from the church by some of the non-intrusionists led by Dr
      <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Chalmers" title="Thomas Chalmers">
       Thomas Chalmers
      </a>
      , known as the Great
      <a href="/wiki/Disruption_of_1843" title="Disruption of 1843">
       Disruption of 1843
      </a>
      . Roughly a third of the clergy, mainly from the North and Highlands, formed the separate
      <a href="/wiki/Free_Church_of_Scotland_(1843%E2%80%931900)" title="Free Church of Scotland (1843–1900)">
       Free Church of Scotland
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Robb1990_104-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Robb1990-104">
        [104]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the late 19th century growing divisions between fundamentalist Calvinists and theological liberals resulted in a further split in the Free Church as the rigid Calvinists broke away to form the
      <a href="/wiki/Free_Presbyterian_Church_of_Scotland" title="Free Presbyterian Church of Scotland">
       Free Presbyterian Church
      </a>
      in 1893.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koch2006p416-7_105-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Koch2006p416-7-105">
        [105]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_Emancipation" title="Catholic Emancipation">
       Catholic Emancipation
      </a>
      in 1829 and the influx of large numbers of Irish immigrants, particularly after the famine years of the late 1840s, mainly to the growing lowland centres like Glasgow, led to a transformation in the fortunes of Catholicism. In 1878, despite opposition, a Roman Catholic ecclesiastical hierarchy was restored to the country, and Catholicism became a significant denomination within Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koch2006p416-7_105-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Koch2006p416-7-105">
        [105]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Industrialisation, urbanisation and the Disruption of 1843 all undermined the tradition of parish schools. From 1830 the state began to fund buildings with grants; then from 1846 it was funding schools by direct sponsorship; and in 1872 Scotland moved to a system like that in England of state-sponsored largely free schools, run by local school boards.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Devine2001p91-100_106-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Devine2001p91-100-106">
        [106]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The historic
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Glasgow" title="University of Glasgow">
       University of Glasgow
      </a>
      became a leader in British higher education by providing the educational needs of youth from the urban and commercial classes, as opposed to the upper class.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        [107]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_University_of_St_Andrews" title="The University of St Andrews">
       The University of St Andrews
      </a>
      pioneered the admission of women to Scottish universities. From 1892 Scottish universities could admit and graduate women and the numbers of women at Scottish universities steadily increased until the early 20th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rayner-Canham2008_108-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Rayner-Canham2008-108">
        [108]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_20th_century">
       Early 20th century
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="798" data-file-width="800" height="219" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg/220px-Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg/330px-Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg/440px-Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Scots_with_flag_01-1945.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scots" title="Royal Scots">
         Royal Scots
        </a>
        with a captured
        <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">
         Japanese
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Good_Luck_Flag" title="Good Luck Flag">
         Hinomaru Yosegaki
        </a>
        flag,
        <a href="/wiki/British_rule_in_Burma" title="British rule in Burma">
         Burma
        </a>
        , 1945.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Scotland played a major role in the British effort in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">
       First World War
      </a>
      . It especially provided manpower, ships, machinery, fish and money.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        [109]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With a population of 4.8 million in 1911, Scotland sent over half a million men to the war, of whom over a quarter died in combat or from disease, and 150,000 were seriously wounded.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Field_Marshal_(United_Kingdom)" title="Field Marshal (United Kingdom)">
       Field Marshal
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Douglas_Haig" title="Douglas Haig">
       Sir Douglas Haig
      </a>
      was Britain's commander on the Western Front.
     </p>
     <p>
      The war saw the emergence of a radical movement called "
      <a href="/wiki/Red_Clydeside" title="Red Clydeside">
       Red Clydeside
      </a>
      " led by militant trades unionists. Formerly a
      <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK)" title="Liberal Party (UK)">
       Liberal
      </a>
      stronghold, the industrial districts switched to
      <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">
       Labour
      </a>
      by 1922, with a base among the
      <a href="/wiki/Irish_Catholic" title="Irish Catholic">
       Irish Catholic
      </a>
      working class districts. Women were especially active in building neighbourhood solidarity on housing issues. However, the "Reds" operated within the Labour Party and had little influence in Parliament and the mood changed to passive despair by the late 1920s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        [111]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The shipbuilding industry expanded by a third and expected renewed prosperity, but instead a serious depression hit the economy by 1922 and it did not fully recover until 1939. The interwar years were marked by economic stagnation in rural and urban areas, and high unemployment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Indeed, the war brought with it deep social, cultural, economic, and political dislocations. Thoughtful Scots pondered their declension, as the main social indicators such as poor health, bad housing, and long-term mass unemployment, pointed to terminal social and economic stagnation at best, or even a downward spiral. Service abroad on behalf of the Empire lost its allure to ambitious young people, who left Scotland permanently. The heavy dependence on obsolescent heavy industry and mining was a central problem, and no one offered workable solutions. The despair reflected what Finlay (1994) describes as a widespread sense of hopelessness that prepared local business and political leaders to accept a new orthodoxy of centralised government economic planning when it arrived during the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">
       Second World War
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        [113]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">
       Second World War
      </a>
      brought renewed prosperity, despite extensive bombing of cities by the Luftwaffe. It saw the invention of radar by
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Watson-Watt" title="Robert Watson-Watt">
       Robert Watson-Watt
      </a>
      , which was invaluable in the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">
       Battle of Britain
      </a>
      as was the leadership at
      <a href="/wiki/RAF_Fighter_Command" title="RAF Fighter Command">
       RAF Fighter Command
      </a>
      of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_Chief_Marshal_(UK)" title="Air Chief Marshal (UK)">
       Air Chief Marshal
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Dowding" title="Hugh Dowding">
       Sir Hugh Dowding
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
       <a href="#cite_note-114">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Since_1945">
       Since 1945
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      After 1945, Scotland's economic situation became progressively worse due to overseas competition, inefficient industry, and industrial disputes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
       <a href="#cite_note-115">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Only in recent decades has the country enjoyed something of a cultural and economic renaissance. Economic factors contributing to this recovery include a resurgent financial services industry,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electronics_manufacturing" title="Electronics manufacturing">
       electronics manufacturing
      </a>
      , (see
      <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Glen" title="Silicon Glen">
       Silicon Glen
      </a>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
       <a href="#cite_note-116">
        [116]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">
       North Sea oil
      </a>
      and gas industry.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        [117]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The introduction in 1989 by Margaret Thatcher's government of the
      <a href="/wiki/Community_Charge" title="Community Charge">
       Community Charge
      </a>
      (widely known as the Poll Tax) one year before the rest of the United Kingdom, contributed to a growing movement for a return to direct Scottish control over domestic affairs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
       <a href="#cite_note-118">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following a
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_devolution_referendum,_1997" title="Scottish devolution referendum, 1997">
       referendum on devolution proposals in 1997
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Act_1998" title="Scotland Act 1998">
       Scotland Act 1998
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      was passed by the United Kingdom Parliament to establish a devolved
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">
       Scottish Parliament
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">
       Scottish Government
      </a>
      with responsibility for most laws specific to Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
       Education
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">
       Scottish education system
      </a>
      has always remained distinct from the rest of the United Kingdom, with a characteristic emphasis on a
      <a href="/wiki/Liberal_education" title="Liberal education">
       broad education
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
       <a href="#cite_note-121">
        [121]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 15th century, the Humanist emphasis on education cumulated with the passing of the
      <a href="/wiki/Education_Act_1496" title="Education Act 1496">
       Education Act 1496
      </a>
      , which decreed that all sons of barons and freeholders of substance should attend grammar schools to learn "perfyct Latyne", resulting in an increase in literacy among a male and wealthy elite.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bawcutt.26Williams2006pp29-30_122-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bawcutt.26Williams2006pp29-30-122">
        [122]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the Reformation the 1560
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Book_of_Discipline" title="First Book of Discipline">
        First Book of Discipline
       </a>
      </i>
      set out a plan for a school in every parish, but this proved financially impossible.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
       <a href="#cite_note-123">
        [123]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1616 an
      <a href="/wiki/School_Establishment_Act_1616" title="School Establishment Act 1616">
       act in Privy council
      </a>
      commanded every parish to establish a school.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        [124]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By the late seventeenth century there was a largely complete network of parish schools in the lowlands, but in the Highlands basic education was still lacking in many areas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anderson2003_125-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Anderson2003-125">
        [125]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Education remained a matter for the church rather than the state until the
      <a href="/wiki/Elementary_Education_Act_1870" title="Elementary Education Act 1870">
       Education Act (1872)
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
       <a href="#cite_note-126">
        [126]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_natural_history">
       Geography and natural history
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Scotland" title="Geography of Scotland">
       Geography of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:489px;max-width:489px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:243px;max-width:243px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Little_Cumbrae.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="2120" data-file-width="2816" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Little_Cumbrae.JPG/241px-Little_Cumbrae.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Little_Cumbrae.JPG/362px-Little_Cumbrae.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Little_Cumbrae.JPG/482px-Little_Cumbrae.JPG 2x" width="241"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:242px;max-width:242px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Traigh_Sheilebost.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Traigh_Sheilebost.jpg/240px-Traigh_Sheilebost.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Traigh_Sheilebost.jpg/360px-Traigh_Sheilebost.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Traigh_Sheilebost.jpg/480px-Traigh_Sheilebost.jpg 2x" width="240"/>
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div style="clear:left">
       </div>
       <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
        The island of
        <a href="/wiki/Little_Cumbrae" title="Little Cumbrae">
         Little Cumbrae
        </a>
        with
        <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Arran" title="Isle of Arran">
         Isle of Arran
        </a>
        in the background (left). Traigh Seilebost Beach on the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isle_of_Harris" title="Isle of Harris">
         Isle of Harris
        </a>
        (right)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The mainland of Scotland comprises the northern third of the land mass of the island of Great Britain, which lies off the north-west coast of
      <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">
       Continental Europe
      </a>
      . The total area is 78,772 km
      <sup>
       2
      </sup>
      (30,414 sq mi),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Whitaker_127-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Whitaker-127">
        [127]
       </a>
      </sup>
      comparable to the size of the Czech Republic. Scotland's only land border is with England, and runs for 96 kilometres (60 mi) between the basin of the
      <a href="/wiki/River_Tweed" title="River Tweed">
       River Tweed
      </a>
      on the east coast and the
      <a href="/wiki/Solway_Firth" title="Solway Firth">
       Solway Firth
      </a>
      in the west. The Atlantic Ocean borders the west coast and the
      <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">
       North Sea
      </a>
      is to the east. The island of Ireland lies only 21 kilometres (13 mi) from the south-western peninsula of
      <a href="/wiki/Kintyre" title="Kintyre">
       Kintyre
      </a>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
       <a href="#cite_note-128">
        [128]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Norway is 305 kilometres (190 mi) to the east and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Faroes" title="Faroes">
       Faroes
      </a>
      , 270 kilometres (168 mi) to the north.
     </p>
     <p>
      The territorial extent of Scotland is generally that established by the 1237
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_York" title="Treaty of York">
       Treaty of York
      </a>
      between Scotland and the Kingdom of England
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
       <a href="#cite_note-129">
        [129]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the 1266
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Perth" title="Treaty of Perth">
       Treaty of Perth
      </a>
      between Scotland and Norway.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mackie_18-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mackie-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Important exceptions include the
      <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">
       Isle of Man
      </a>
      , which having been lost to England in the 14th century is now a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crown_dependency" title="Crown dependency">
       crown dependency
      </a>
      outside of the United Kingdom; the island groups
      <a href="/wiki/Orkney" title="Orkney">
       Orkney
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Shetland" title="Shetland">
       Shetland
      </a>
      , which were acquired from Norway in 1472;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Whitaker_127-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Whitaker-127">
        [127]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Berwick-upon-Tweed" title="Berwick-upon-Tweed">
       Berwick-upon-Tweed
      </a>
      , lost to England in 1482.
     </p>
     <p>
      The geographical centre of Scotland lies a few miles from the village of
      <a href="/wiki/Newtonmore" title="Newtonmore">
       Newtonmore
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Badenoch" title="Badenoch">
       Badenoch
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
       <a href="#cite_note-130">
        [130]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Rising to 1,344 metres (4,409 ft) above sea level, Scotland's highest point is the summit of
      <a href="/wiki/Ben_Nevis" title="Ben Nevis">
       Ben Nevis
      </a>
      , in
      <a href="/wiki/Lochaber" title="Lochaber">
       Lochaber
      </a>
      , while Scotland's longest river, the
      <a href="/wiki/River_Tay" title="River Tay">
       River Tay
      </a>
      , flows for a distance of 190 kilometres (118 mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
       <a href="#cite_note-131">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
       <a href="#cite_note-132">
        [132]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Geology_and_geomorphology">
       Geology and geomorphology
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Scotland" title="Geology of Scotland">
       Geology of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scotland_(Location)_Named_(HR).png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="759" data-file-width="455" height="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Scotland_%28Location%29_Named_%28HR%29.png/170px-Scotland_%28Location%29_Named_%28HR%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Scotland_%28Location%29_Named_%28HR%29.png/255px-Scotland_%28Location%29_Named_%28HR%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Scotland_%28Location%29_Named_%28HR%29.png/340px-Scotland_%28Location%29_Named_%28HR%29.png 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scotland_(Location)_Named_(HR).png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Relief map of Scotland
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The whole of Scotland was covered by ice sheets during the
      <a href="/wiki/Pleistocene" title="Pleistocene">
       Pleistocene
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ice_ages" title="Ice ages">
       ice ages
      </a>
      and the landscape is much affected by glaciation. From a geological perspective, the country has three main sub-divisions.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Highlands_and_Islands" title="Highlands and Islands">
       Highlands and Islands
      </a>
      lie to the north and west of the
      <a href="/wiki/Highland_Boundary_Fault" title="Highland Boundary Fault">
       Highland Boundary Fault
      </a>
      , which runs from
      <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Arran" title="Isle of Arran">
       Arran
      </a>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/Stonehaven" title="Stonehaven">
       Stonehaven
      </a>
      . This part of Scotland largely comprises ancient rocks from the
      <a href="/wiki/Cambrian" title="Cambrian">
       Cambrian
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Precambrian" title="Precambrian">
       Precambrian
      </a>
      , which were uplifted during the later
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caledonian_Orogeny" title="Caledonian Orogeny">
       Caledonian Orogeny
      </a>
      . It is interspersed with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Igneous" title="Igneous">
       igneous
      </a>
      intrusions of a more recent age, remnants of which formed mountain massifs such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Cairngorms" title="Cairngorms">
       Cairngorms
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Skye" title="Skye">
       Skye
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuillins" title="Cuillins">
       Cuillins
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      A significant exception to the above are the fossil-bearing beds of
      <a href="/wiki/Old_Red_Sandstone" title="Old Red Sandstone">
       Old Red Sandstones
      </a>
      found principally along the
      <a href="/wiki/Moray_Firth" title="Moray Firth">
       Moray Firth
      </a>
      coast. The
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">
       Highlands
      </a>
      are generally mountainous and the highest elevations in the British Isles are found here. Scotland has over 790 islands divided into four main groups: Shetland, Orkney, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Inner_Hebrides" title="Inner Hebrides">
       Inner Hebrides
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Outer_Hebrides" title="Outer Hebrides">
       Outer Hebrides
      </a>
      . There are numerous bodies of freshwater including
      <a href="/wiki/Loch_Lomond" title="Loch Lomond">
       Loch Lomond
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Loch_Ness" title="Loch Ness">
       Loch Ness
      </a>
      . Some parts of the coastline consist of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Machair_(geography)" title="Machair (geography)">
       machair
      </a>
      , a low lying dune pasture land.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Lowlands" title="Central Lowlands">
       Central Lowlands
      </a>
      is a
      <a href="/wiki/Rift_valley" title="Rift valley">
       rift valley
      </a>
      mainly comprising
      <a href="/wiki/Paleozoic" title="Paleozoic">
       Paleozoic
      </a>
      formations. Many of these sediments have economic significance for it is here that the coal and iron bearing rocks that fuelled Scotland's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Industrial_revolution" title="Industrial revolution">
       industrial revolution
      </a>
      are found. This area has also experienced intense volcanism,
      <a href="/wiki/Arthur%27s_Seat" title="Arthur's Seat">
       Arthur's Seat
      </a>
      in Edinburgh being the remnant of a once much larger volcano. This area is relatively low-lying, although even here hills such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Ochil_Hills" title="Ochil Hills">
       Ochils
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Campsie_Fells" title="Campsie Fells">
       Campsie Fells
      </a>
      are rarely far from view.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Uplands" title="Southern Uplands">
       Southern Uplands
      </a>
      are a range of hills almost 200 kilometres (124 mi) long, interspersed with broad valleys. They lie south of a second
      <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">
       fault line
      </a>
      (the Southern Uplands fault) that runs from
      <a href="/wiki/Girvan" title="Girvan">
       Girvan
      </a>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/Dunbar" title="Dunbar">
       Dunbar
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
       <a href="#cite_note-133">
        [133]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        [134]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scotland_Today_.C2.BB_ITKT_135-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Scotland_Today_.C2.BB_ITKT-135">
        [135]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The geological foundations largely comprise
      <a href="/wiki/Silurian" title="Silurian">
       Silurian
      </a>
      deposits laid down some 4–500 million years ago. The high point of the Southern Uplands is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Merrick,_Galloway" title="Merrick, Galloway">
       Merrick
      </a>
      with an elevation of 843 m (2,766 ft).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keay_17-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Keay-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
       <a href="#cite_note-136">
        [136]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
       <a href="#cite_note-137">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Southern Uplands is home to the UK's highest village,
      <a href="/wiki/Wanlockhead" title="Wanlockhead">
       Wanlockhead
      </a>
      (430 m or 1,411 ft above sea level).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scotland_Today_.C2.BB_ITKT_135-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Scotland_Today_.C2.BB_ITKT-135">
        [135]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
       Climate
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tiree,_Balephuil_Bay.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="425" data-file-width="640" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Tiree%2C_Balephuil_Bay.jpg/220px-Tiree%2C_Balephuil_Bay.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Tiree%2C_Balephuil_Bay.jpg/330px-Tiree%2C_Balephuil_Bay.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Tiree%2C_Balephuil_Bay.jpg/440px-Tiree%2C_Balephuil_Bay.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tiree,_Balephuil_Bay.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Tiree" title="Tiree">
         Tiree
        </a>
        , one of the sunniest locations in Scotland
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Scotland" title="Climate of Scotland">
       Climate of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The climate of Scotland is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temperate" title="Temperate">
       temperate
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">
       oceanic
      </a>
      , and tends to be very changeable. As it is warmed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Stream" title="Gulf Stream">
       Gulf Stream
      </a>
      from the
      <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">
       Atlantic
      </a>
      , it has much milder winters (but cooler, wetter summers) than areas on similar latitudes, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Labrador" title="Labrador">
       Labrador
      </a>
      , southern
      <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">
       Scandinavia
      </a>
      , the Moscow region in Russia, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Kamchatka_Peninsula" title="Kamchatka Peninsula">
       Kamchatka Peninsula
      </a>
      on the opposite side of
      <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">
       Eurasia
      </a>
      . However, temperatures are generally lower than in the rest of the UK, with the coldest ever UK temperature of −27.2 °C (−17.0 °F) recorded at
      <a href="/wiki/Braemar" title="Braemar">
       Braemar
      </a>
      in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grampian_Mountains_(Scotland)" title="Grampian Mountains (Scotland)">
       Grampian Mountains
      </a>
      , on 11 February 1895.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
       <a href="#cite_note-139">
        [139]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Winter maxima average 6 °C (42.8 °F) in the Lowlands, with summer maxima averaging 18 °C (64.4 °F). The highest temperature recorded was 32.9 °C (91.2 °F) at
      <a href="/wiki/Greycrook" title="Greycrook">
       Greycrook
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Borders" title="Scottish Borders">
       Scottish Borders
      </a>
      on 9 August 2003.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Metext_140-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Metext-140">
        [140]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The west of Scotland is usually warmer than the east, owing to the influence of Atlantic
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ocean_currents" title="Ocean currents">
       ocean currents
      </a>
      and the colder surface temperatures of the
      <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">
       North Sea
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Tiree" title="Tiree">
       Tiree
      </a>
      , in the Inner Hebrides, is one of the sunniest places in the country: it had more than 300 hours of sunshine in May 1975.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Metext_140-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Metext-140">
        [140]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Rainfall varies widely across Scotland. The western highlands of Scotland are the wettest, with annual rainfall in a few places exceeding 3,000 mm (118.1 in).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        [141]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In comparison, much of lowland Scotland receives less than 800 mm (31.5 in) annually.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteast_142-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteast-142">
        [142]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Heavy snowfall is not common in the lowlands, but becomes more common with altitude. Braemar has an average of 59 snow days per year,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        [143]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while many coastal areas average fewer than 10 days of lying snow per year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meteast_142-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Meteast-142">
        [142]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Flora_and_fauna">
       Flora and fauna
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lepus_timidus_01-cropped.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="223" data-file-width="323" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Lepus_timidus_01-cropped.jpg/220px-Lepus_timidus_01-cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/86/Lepus_timidus_01-cropped.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lepus_timidus_01-cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Mountain_hare" title="Mountain hare">
         mountain hare
        </a>
        <span style="font-size:90%;">
         (
         <i>
          Lepus timidus
         </i>
         )
        </span>
        photographed in Findhorn Valley, May 2004
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Scotland" title="Fauna of Scotland">
       Fauna of Scotland
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Scotland" title="Flora of Scotland">
       Flora of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Scotland's wildlife is typical of the north-west of Europe, although several of the larger mammals such as the lynx, brown bear, wolf, elk and walrus were hunted to extinction in historic times. There are important populations of seals and internationally significant nesting grounds for a variety of seabirds such as
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_gannet" title="Northern gannet">
       gannets
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Golden_eagle" title="Golden eagle">
       golden eagle
      </a>
      is something of a national icon.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        [145]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On the high mountain tops, species including
      <a href="/wiki/Rock_ptarmigan" title="Rock ptarmigan">
       ptarmigan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mountain_hare" title="Mountain hare">
       mountain hare
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Stoat" title="Stoat">
       stoat
      </a>
      can be seen in their white colour phase during winter months.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
       <a href="#cite_note-146">
        [146]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Remnants of the native
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_pine" title="Scots pine">
       Scots pine
      </a>
      forest exist
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
       <a href="#cite_note-147">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and within these areas the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_crossbill" title="Scottish crossbill">
       Scottish crossbill
      </a>
      , the UK's only
      <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">
       endemic
      </a>
      bird species and
      <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">
       vertebrate
      </a>
      , can be found alongside
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Capercaillie" title="Capercaillie">
       capercaillie
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Wildcat" title="Wildcat">
       wildcat
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Red_squirrel" title="Red squirrel">
       red squirrel
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pine_marten" title="Pine marten">
       pine marten
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
       <a href="#cite_note-148">
        [148]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
       <a href="#cite_note-149">
        [149]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
       <a href="#cite_note-150">
        [150]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In recent years various animals have been re-introduced, including the
      <a href="/wiki/White-tailed_eagle" title="White-tailed eagle">
       white-tailed sea eagle
      </a>
      in 1975, the
      <a href="/wiki/Red_kite" title="Red kite">
       red kite
      </a>
      in the 1980s,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
       <a href="#cite_note-151">
        [151]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        [152]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and more recently there have been experimental projects involving the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_beaver" title="European beaver">
       beaver
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">
       wild boar
      </a>
      . Today, much of the remaining native
      <a href="/wiki/Caledonian_Forest" title="Caledonian Forest">
       Caledonian Forest
      </a>
      lies within the
      <a href="/wiki/Cairngorms_National_Park" title="Cairngorms National Park">
       Cairngorms National Park
      </a>
      and remnants of the forest remain at 84 locations across Scotland. On the west coast, remnants of ancient Celtic Rainforest still remain, particularly on the Taynish peninsula in
      <a href="/wiki/Argyll" title="Argyll">
       Argyll
      </a>
      , these forests are particularly rare due to high rates of deforestation throughout Scottish history.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
       <a href="#cite_note-153">
        [153]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_News_154-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-154">
        [154]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The flora of the country is varied incorporating both
      <a href="/wiki/Deciduous" title="Deciduous">
       deciduous
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coniferous" title="Coniferous">
       coniferous
      </a>
      woodland and
      <a href="/wiki/Moorland" title="Moorland">
       moorland
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">
       tundra
      </a>
      species. However, large scale commercial tree planting and the management of upland moorland habitat for the grazing of sheep and commercial field sport activities impacts upon the distribution of
      <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_(ecology)" title="Indigenous (ecology)">
       indigenous
      </a>
      plants and animals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        [155]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The UK's tallest tree is a
      <a href="/wiki/Abies_grandis" title="Abies grandis">
       grand fir
      </a>
      planted beside
      <a href="/wiki/Loch_Fyne" title="Loch Fyne">
       Loch Fyne
      </a>
      , Argyll in the 1870s, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Fortingall_Yew" title="Fortingall Yew">
       Fortingall Yew
      </a>
      may be 5,000 years old and is probably the oldest living thing in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
       <a href="#cite_note-156">
        [156]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
       <a href="#cite_note-157">
        [157]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
       <a href="#cite_note-158">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although the number of native
      <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">
       vascular plants
      </a>
      is low by world standards, Scotland's substantial
      <a href="/wiki/Bryophyte" title="Bryophyte">
       bryophyte
      </a>
      flora is of global importance.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
       <a href="#cite_note-159">
        [159]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RBGE_160-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RBGE-160">
        [160]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
       Demographics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <table class="wikitable" style="float:right; clear:right; font-size:90%; margin-left:15px;">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="4">
        <div style="text-align:center; position:relative; white-space:nowrap;">

         <br/>
         by ethnic group (2011)
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity.28deadlink.29_161-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-ethnicity.28deadlink.29-161">
           [161]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="position:absolute; right:0; top:0; margin:0 5px;">
          <ul>

      </tr>
     </table>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_Scotland" title="Demography of Scotland">
       Demography of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Scotland" title="Languages of Scotland">
       Languages of Scotland
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Scotland" title="Religion in Scotland">
       Religion in Scotland
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_people" title="Scottish people">
       Scottish people
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The population of Scotland at the 2001 Census was 5,062,011. This rose to 5,295,400, the highest ever, at the 2011 Census.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_162-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-162">
        [162]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the 2011 Census, 62% of Scotland's population stated their
      <a href="/wiki/National_identity" title="National identity">
       national identity
      </a>
      as '
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_people" title="Scottish people">
       Scottish
      </a>
      only', 18% as 'Scottish and British', 8% as 'British only', and 4% chose other national identities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        [163]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Although Edinburgh is the capital of Scotland, the largest city is Glasgow, which has just over 584,000 inhabitants. The
      <a href="/wiki/Greater_Glasgow" title="Greater Glasgow">
       Greater Glasgow
      </a>
      conurbation, with a population of almost 1.2 million, is home to nearly a quarter of Scotland's population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
       <a href="#cite_note-164">
        [164]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Belt" title="Central Belt">
       Central Belt
      </a>
      is where most of the main towns and cities are located, including Glasgow, Edinburgh, Dundee and Perth. Scotland's only major city outside the Central Belt is Aberdeen.
     </p>
     <p>
      In general, only the more accessible and larger islands remain inhabited. Currently, fewer than 90 remain inhabited. The Southern Uplands are essentially rural in nature and dominated by agriculture and forestry.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
       <a href="#cite_note-165">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
       <a href="#cite_note-166">
        [166]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Because of housing problems in Glasgow and Edinburgh, five
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_town#United_Kingdom" title="New town">
       new towns
      </a>
      were created between 1947 and 1966. They are
      <a href="/wiki/East_Kilbride" title="East Kilbride">
       East Kilbride
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Glenrothes" title="Glenrothes">
       Glenrothes
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Livingston,_West_Lothian" title="Livingston, West Lothian">
       Livingston
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cumbernauld" title="Cumbernauld">
       Cumbernauld
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Irvine,_North_Ayrshire" title="Irvine, North Ayrshire">
       Irvine
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
       <a href="#cite_note-167">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Immigration since World War II has given Glasgow, Edinburgh and Dundee small South Asian communities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
       <a href="#cite_note-168">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2011, there were an estimated 49,000 ethnically Pakistani people living in Scotland, making them the largest non-White ethnic group.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ethnicity-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the
      <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">
       Enlargement of the European Union
      </a>
      more people from
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">
       Central
      </a>
      and Eastern Europe have moved to Scotland, and the 2011 census indicated that 61,000
      <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">
       Poles
      </a>
      live there.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity_5-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-ethnicity-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
       <a href="#cite_note-169">
        [169]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scotland_population_cartogram.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="858" data-file-width="950" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Scotland_population_cartogram.png/220px-Scotland_population_cartogram.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Scotland_population_cartogram.png/330px-Scotland_population_cartogram.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Scotland_population_cartogram.png/440px-Scotland_population_cartogram.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scotland_population_cartogram.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Scotland population
        <a href="/wiki/Cartogram" title="Cartogram">
         cartogram
        </a>
        . The size of councils is in proportion to their population; the darker the colour, the bigger the actual area served by a council.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Scotland has three officially recognised languages: English,
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">
       Scots
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">
       Scottish Gaelic
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
       <a href="#cite_note-170">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        [171]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scottish Standard English, a variety of English as spoken in Scotland, is at one end of a bipolar
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Linguistic_continuum" title="Linguistic continuum">
       linguistic continuum
      </a>
      , with broad
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">
       Scots
      </a>
      at the other.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
       <a href="#cite_note-172">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scottish Standard English may have been influenced to varying degrees by Scots.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stuart-Smith_J._2008._p.48_173-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Stuart-Smith_J._2008._p.48-173">
        [173]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        [174]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The 2011 census indicated that 63% of the population had "no skills in Scots".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
       <a href="#cite_note-175">
        [175]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Others speak
      <a href="/wiki/Highland_English" title="Highland English">
       Highland English
      </a>
      . Gaelic is mostly spoken in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Isles" title="Western Isles">
       Western Isles
      </a>
      , where a large proportion of people still speak it; however, nationally its use is confined to just 1% of the population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
       <a href="#cite_note-176">
        [176]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The number of Gaelic speakers in Scotland dropped from 250,000 in 1881 to 60,000 in 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
       <a href="#cite_note-177">
        [177]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There are many more people with Scottish ancestry living abroad than the total population of Scotland. In the 2000 Census, 9.2 million Americans self-reported some degree of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_American" title="Scottish American">
       Scottish
      </a>
      descent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
       <a href="#cite_note-178">
        [178]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Ulster" title="Ulster">
       Ulster
      </a>
      's Protestant population is mainly of lowland Scottish descent,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
       <a href="#cite_note-179">
        [179]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and it is estimated that there are more than 27 million descendants of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ulster_Scots_people" title="Ulster Scots people">
       Scots-Irish
      </a>
      migration now living in the US.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
       <a href="#cite_note-180">
        [180]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
       <a href="#cite_note-181">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In Canada, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish-Canadian" title="Scottish-Canadian">
       Scottish-Canadian
      </a>
      community accounts for 4.7 million people.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cancensus_182-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-cancensus-182">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      About 20% of the original European settler population of New Zealand came from Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
       <a href="#cite_note-183">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In August 2012, the Scottish population reached an all-time high of 5.25 million people.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thecourier1_184-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-thecourier1-184">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The reasons given were that, in Scotland, births were outnumbering the number of deaths, and immigrants were moving to Scotland from overseas. In 2011, 43,700 people moved from Wales, Northern Ireland or England to live in Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thecourier1_184-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-thecourier1-184">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">
       total fertility rate
      </a>
      (TFR) in Scotland is below the replacement rate of 2.1 (the TFR was 1.73 in 2011
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
       <a href="#cite_note-185">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ). The majority of births today are to unmarried women (51.3% of births were outside of marriage in 2012
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
       <a href="#cite_note-186">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ).
     </p>
     <table class="navbox">
      <tr>
       <th class="navbox-title" colspan="10">
        <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
        </div>
        <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">
         <ul>
          <li class="nv-view">
           <a href="/wiki/Template:Largest_cities_of_Scotland" title="Template:Largest cities of Scotland">
            <abbr title="View this template">
             v
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-talk">
           <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Largest_cities_of_Scotland" title="Template talk:Largest cities of Scotland">
            <abbr title="Discuss this template">
             t
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-edit">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit">
            <abbr title="Edit this template">
             e
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
        <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
         <span style="font-size:110%;">
          Largest cities or towns in Scotland
         </span>
         <br/>
         <span style="font-weight:normal;">
          <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011#2011_Census_for_Scotland" title="United Kingdom Census 2011">
           Scotland's Census 2011
          </a>
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011_census_187-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-2011_census-187">
            [187]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </span>
        </div>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th>
       </th>

        36,142
       </td>

     </table>
     <p>
      Life expectancy for those born in Scotland between 2010 and 2012 is 76.5 years for males and 80.7 years for females.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-life_188-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-life-188">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This is the lowest of any of the four countries of the UK.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-life_188-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-life-188">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
       Religion
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Scotland" title="Religion in Scotland">
       Religion in Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iona_Abbey.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="384" data-file-width="579" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Iona_Abbey.jpg/220px-Iona_Abbey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Iona_Abbey.jpg/330px-Iona_Abbey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Iona_Abbey.jpg/440px-Iona_Abbey.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iona_Abbey.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Iona_Abbey" title="Iona Abbey">
         Iona Abbey
        </a>
        , an early centre of Christianity in Scotland
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Just over half (54%) of the Scottish population reported being a Christian while nearly 37% reported not having a religion in a 2011 census.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011_census_religion_189-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-2011_census_religion-189">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Reformation" title="Scottish Reformation">
       Scottish Reformation
      </a>
      of 1560, the
      <a href="/wiki/National_church" title="National church">
       national church
      </a>
      (the
      <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Scotland" title="Church of Scotland">
       Church of Scotland
      </a>
      , also known as
      <a href="/wiki/Kirk" title="Kirk">
       The Kirk
      </a>
      ) has been
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">
       Protestant
      </a>
      in classification and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reformed_theology" title="Reformed theology">
       Reformed
      </a>
      in theology. Since 1689 it has had a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterian" title="Presbyterian">
       Presbyterian
      </a>
      system of church government, and enjoys independence from the state.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keay_17-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Keay-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Its membership is 398,389,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scotsman.com_190-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-scotsman.com-190">
        [190]
       </a>
      </sup>
      about 7.5% of the total population, though according to the 2014 Scottish Annual Household Survey, 27.8%, or 1.5 million adherents, identified Church of Scotland as their religion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
       <a href="#cite_note-191">
        [191]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Church operates a territorial parish structure, with every community in Scotland having a local congregation.
     </p>
     <p>
      Scotland also has a significant
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church_in_Scotland" title="Roman Catholic Church in Scotland">
       Roman Catholic
      </a>
      population, 19% claiming that faith, particularly in the west.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
       <a href="#cite_note-192">
        [192]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the Reformation, Roman Catholicism in Scotland continued in the Highlands and some western islands like
      <a href="/wiki/Uist" title="Uist">
       Uist
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Barra" title="Barra">
       Barra
      </a>
      , and it was strengthened during the 19th century by immigration from Ireland. Other Christian denominations in Scotland include the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free_Church_of_Scotland_(post_1900)" title="Free Church of Scotland (post 1900)">
       Free Church of Scotland
      </a>
      , and various other Presbyterian offshoots. "Scotland's third largest church" is the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Episcopal_Church" title="Scottish Episcopal Church">
       Scottish Episcopal Church
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
       <a href="#cite_note-193">
        [193]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Islam is the largest non-Christian religion (estimated at around 75,000, which is about 1.4% of the population),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011_census_religion_189-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-2011_census_religion-189">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GROSCOT_194-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GROSCOT-194">
        [194]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and there are also significant
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Scotland" title="History of the Jews in Scotland">
       Jewish
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Scotland" title="Hinduism in Scotland">
       Hindu
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sikh" title="Sikh">
       Sikh
      </a>
      communities, especially in Glasgow.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GROSCOT_194-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GROSCOT-194">
        [194]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samy%C3%A9_Ling" title="Samyé Ling">
       Samyé Ling
      </a>
      monastery near
      <a href="/wiki/Eskdalemuir" title="Eskdalemuir">
       Eskdalemuir
      </a>
      , which celebrated its 40th anniversary in 2007, is the first
      <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">
       Buddhist
      </a>
      monastery in western Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
       <a href="#cite_note-195">
        [195]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_government">
       Politics and government
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Scotland" title="Politics of Scotland">
       Politics of Scotland
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">
       Scottish Parliament
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">
       Scottish Government
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2480" data-file-width="3508" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg/220px-The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg/330px-The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg/440px-The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Queen_at_the_Scottish_Parliament.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Scotland" title="Crown of Scotland">
         Crown of Scotland
        </a>
        is carried by
        <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Douglas-Hamilton,_16th_Duke_of_Hamilton" title="Alexander Douglas-Hamilton, 16th Duke of Hamilton">
         The Duke of Hamilton
        </a>
        when
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II" title="Queen Elizabeth II">
         Queen Elizabeth II
        </a>
        attends the
        <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">
         Scottish Parliament
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Scotland's head of state is the monarch of the United Kingdom, currently
      <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">
       Queen Elizabeth II
      </a>
      (since 1952). The
      <a href="/wiki/Regnal_number" title="Regnal number">
       regnal numbering
      </a>
      "Elizabeth II" caused
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_titles_and_honours_of_Queen_Elizabeth_II#Scottish_controversy" title="List of titles and honours of Queen Elizabeth II">
       controversy
      </a>
      around the time of the Queen's coronation because there had never been an Elizabeth I in Scotland. A legal action,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MacCormick_v._Lord_Advocate" title="MacCormick v. Lord Advocate">
       MacCormick v. Lord Advocate
      </a>
      (1953 SC 396), was brought to contest the right of the Queen to entitle herself
      <i>
       Elizabeth II
      </i>
      within Scotland, arguing that this was a breach of Article 1 of the Treaty of Union.
      <a href="/wiki/The_Crown" title="The Crown">
       The Crown
      </a>
      won the case. It was decided that future British monarchs would be numbered according to either their English or their Scottish predecessors, whichever number is higher.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
       <a href="#cite_note-196">
        [196]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For instance any future King James would be styled James VIII—since the last Scottish King James was
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_VII_of_Scotland" title="James VII of Scotland">
       James VII
      </a>
      (also James II of England, etc.)—while the next King Henry would be King Henry IX throughout the UK even though there have been no Scottish kings of that name.
     </p>
     <p>
      Scotland has limited
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Self-government" title="Self-government">
       self-government
      </a>
      within the United Kingdom, as well as representation in the UK Parliament. Executive and legislative powers respectively have been devolved to the Scottish Government and the Scottish Parliament at
      <a href="/wiki/Holyrood,_Edinburgh" title="Holyrood, Edinburgh">
       Holyrood
      </a>
      in Edinburgh since 1999. The UK Parliament retains control over
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reserved_matters" title="Reserved matters">
       reserved matters
      </a>
      specified in the
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Act_1998" title="Scotland Act 1998">
       Scotland Act 1998
      </a>
      , including UK taxes, social security, defence, international relations and broadcasting.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gate_197-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Gate-197">
        [197]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Scottish Parliament has legislative authority for all other areas relating to Scotland, as well as a limited power to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tartan_Tax" title="Tartan Tax">
       vary income tax
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
       <a href="#cite_note-198">
        [198]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Scottish Parliament can give legislative consent over devolved matters back to the UK Parliament by passing a
      <a href="/wiki/Legislative_Consent_Motion" title="Legislative Consent Motion">
       Legislative Consent Motion
      </a>
      if United Kingdom-wide legislation is considered more appropriate for a certain issue. The programmes of legislation enacted by the Scottish Parliament have seen a divergence in the provision of public services compared to the rest of the UK. For instance, university education and care services for the elderly are free at point of use in Scotland, while fees are paid in the rest of the UK. Scotland was the first country in the UK to ban smoking in enclosed public places.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
       <a href="#cite_note-199">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2801" data-file-width="3922" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg/220px-Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg/330px-Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg/440px-Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Deputy_Secretary_Blinken_Meets_With_Scottish_First_Minister_Sturgeon_-_18490445358.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Sturgeon" title="Nicola Sturgeon">
         Nicola Sturgeon
        </a>
        , current
        <a href="/wiki/First_Minister_of_Scotland" title="First Minister of Scotland">
         First Minister of Scotland
        </a>
        meets with Deputy United States Secretary of State
        <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blinken" title="Tony Blinken">
         Tony Blinken
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Scottish Parliament is a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">
       unicameral
      </a>
      legislature with 129 members (MSPs): 73 of them represent individual constituencies and are elected on a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_past_the_post" title="First past the post">
       first past the post
      </a>
      system; the other 56 are elected in eight different electoral regions by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Additional_member_system_(Scottish_Parliament)" title="Additional member system (Scottish Parliament)">
       additional member system
      </a>
      . MSPs serve for a four-year period (exceptionally five years from 2011–16). The Parliament nominates one of its Members, who is then appointed by the Monarch to serve as
      <a href="/wiki/First_Minister_of_Scotland" title="First Minister of Scotland">
       First Minister
      </a>
      . Other ministers are appointed by the First Minister and serve at his/her discretion. Together they make up the Scottish Government, the executive arm of the devolved government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
       <a href="#cite_note-200">
        [200]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Scottish Government is headed by the First Minister, who is accountable to the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">
       Scottish Parliament
      </a>
      and is the minister of charge of the Scottish Government. The First Minister is also the political leader of Scotland. The Scottish Government also comprises the
      <a href="/wiki/Deputy_First_Minister_of_Scotland" title="Deputy First Minister of Scotland">
       Deputy First Minister
      </a>
      , currently
      <a href="/wiki/John_Swinney" title="John Swinney">
       John Swinney
      </a>
      MSP, who deputises for the First Minister during a period of absence of overseas visits. Alongside the Deputy First Minister's requirements as Deputy, the minister also has a cabinet ministerial responsibility. Swinney is also currently
      <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_Secretary_for_Education_and_Skills" title="Cabinet Secretary for Education and Skills">
       Cabinet Secretary for Education and Skills
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
       <a href="#cite_note-201">
        [201]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Scottish Government's cabinet comprises nine cabinet secretaries, who form the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Cabinet" title="Scottish Cabinet">
       Cabinet of Scotland
      </a>
