      . There are also twelve other ministers, who work alongside the cabinet secretaries in their appointed areas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
       <a href="#cite_note-202">
        [202]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a result, junior ministers do not attend cabinet meetings.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_election,_2016" title="Scottish Parliament election, 2016">
       2016 election
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_National_Party" title="Scottish National Party">
       Scottish National Party
      </a>
      (SNP) won 63 of the 129 seats available.
      <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Sturgeon" title="Nicola Sturgeon">
       Nicola Sturgeon
      </a>
      , the leader of the SNP, has been the First Minister since November 2014. The
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Conservative_Party" title="Scottish Conservative Party">
       Conservative Party
      </a>
      became the largest opposition party in the 2016 elections, with the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Labour_Party" title="Scottish Labour Party">
       Labour Party
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Liberal_Democrats" title="Scottish Liberal Democrats">
       Liberal Democrats
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Green_Party" title="Scottish Green Party">
       Green Party
      </a>
      also represented in the Parliament. The
      <a href="/wiki/Next_Scottish_Parliament_election" title="Next Scottish Parliament election">
       next Scottish Parliament election
      </a>
      is due to be held on 6 May 2021.
     </p>
     <p>
      Scotland is represented in the British House of Commons by 59 MPs elected from territory-based Scottish constituencies. In the most recent
      <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_2015" title="United Kingdom general election, 2015">
       general election
      </a>
      , held on 7 May 2015, the Scottish National Party won 56 of the 59 seats and saw elected the youngest current member of the House of Commons,
      <a href="/wiki/Mhairi_Black" title="Mhairi Black">
       Mhairi Black
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
       <a href="#cite_note-203">
        [203]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Next_United_Kingdom_general_election" title="Next United Kingdom general election">
       next United Kingdom general election
      </a>
      is due to be held in May 2020. The
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Office" title="Scotland Office">
       Scotland Office
      </a>
      represents the UK government in Scotland on reserved matters and represents Scottish interests within the UK government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
       <a href="#cite_note-204">
        [204]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Scotland Office is led by the
      <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Scotland" title="Secretary of State for Scotland">
       Secretary of State for Scotland
      </a>
      , who sits in the
      <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cabinet of the United Kingdom">
       Cabinet of the United Kingdom
      </a>
      ; the current incumbent is
      <a href="/wiki/David_Mundell" title="David Mundell">
       David Mundell
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Constitutional_changes">
       Constitutional changes
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4544" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg/220px-Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg/330px-Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg/440px-Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The debating chamber within the
        <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_Building" title="Scottish Parliament Building">
         Scottish Parliament Building
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      A policy of
      <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">
       devolution
      </a>
      had been advocated by the three main UK parties with varying enthusiasm during recent history. The late Labour leader
      <a href="/wiki/John_Smith_(Labour_Party_leader)" title="John Smith (Labour Party leader)">
       John Smith
      </a>
      described the revival of a Scottish parliament as the "settled will of the Scottish people".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
       <a href="#cite_note-205">
        [205]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The devolved Scottish Parliament was created after a
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_devolution_referendum,_1997" title="Scottish devolution referendum, 1997">
       referendum in 1997
      </a>
      found majority support for both creating the Parliament and granting it limited powers to
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_variable_rate" title="Scottish variable rate">
       vary income tax
      </a>
      . The constitutional status of Scotland is nonetheless subject to ongoing debate.
     </p>
     <p>
      The Scottish National Party (SNP), which supports
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_independence" title="Scottish independence">
       Scottish independence
      </a>
      , was first elected to form the Scottish Government in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_general_election,_2007" title="Scottish Parliament general election, 2007">
       2007
      </a>
      . The new government established a "
      <a href="/wiki/National_Conversation" title="National Conversation">
       National Conversation
      </a>
      " on constitutional issues, proposing a number of options such as increasing the powers of the Scottish Parliament,
      <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">
       federalism
      </a>
      , or a referendum on Scottish independence from the United Kingdom. In rejecting the last option, the three main opposition parties in the Scottish Parliament created a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Calman_Commission" title="Calman Commission">
       commission
      </a>
      to investigate the distribution of powers between devolved Scottish and UK-wide bodies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
       <a href="#cite_note-206">
        [206]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Act_2012" title="Scotland Act 2012">
       Scotland Act 2012
      </a>
      , based on proposals by the commission, was subsequently enacted devolving additional powers to the Scottish Parliament.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
       <a href="#cite_note-207">
        [207]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In August 2009 the SNP proposed a bill to hold a referendum on independence in November 2010. Opposition from all other major parties led to an expected defeat.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferendumBill2010_208-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferendumBill2010-208">
        [208]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Times3Sep09_209-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Times3Sep09-209">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
       <a href="#cite_note-210">
        [210]
       </a>
      </sup>
      After the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_election,_2011" title="Scottish Parliament election, 2011">
       2011 elections
      </a>
      gave the SNP an overall majority in the Scottish Parliament, a
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_independence_referendum,_2014" title="Scottish independence referendum, 2014">
       referendum on independence for Scotland
      </a>
      was held on 18 September 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
       <a href="#cite_note-211">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The referendum rejected independence by a majority of 55% to 45%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
       <a href="#cite_note-212">
        [212]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
       <a href="#cite_note-213">
        [213]
       </a>
      </sup>
      During the campaign, the three main parties in the UK Parliament pledged to extend the powers of the Scottish Parliament.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
       <a href="#cite_note-214">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kelvin_215-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-kelvin-215">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
      An all-party
      <a href="/wiki/Smith_Commission" title="Smith Commission">
       commission
      </a>
      chaired by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lord_Smith_of_Kelvin" title="Lord Smith of Kelvin">
       Lord Smith of Kelvin
      </a>
      was formed,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kelvin_215-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-kelvin-215">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
      which led to a further devolution of powers through the
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland_Act_2016" title="Scotland Act 2016">
       Scotland Act 2016
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Following the referendum on the UK's membership of the European Union on 23 June 2016, where a UK-wide majority voted to withdraw from the EU whilst a majority within Scotland voted to remain, Scotland's
      <a href="/wiki/First_Minister_of_Scotland" title="First Minister of Scotland">
       First Minister
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Sturgeon" title="Nicola Sturgeon">
       Nicola Sturgeon
      </a>
      , announced that as a result a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Scottish_independence_referendum" title="Second Scottish independence referendum">
       new independence referendum
      </a>
      was "highly likely".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
       <a href="#cite_note-216">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
       <a href="#cite_note-217">
        [217]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_subdivisions">
       Administrative subdivisions
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Scotland" title="Subdivisions of Scotland">
       Subdivisions of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg/220px-Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg/330px-Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg/440px-Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Glasgow_City_Chambers_-_geograph.org.uk_-_646308.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Glasgow_City_Chambers" title="Glasgow City Chambers">
         Glasgow City Chambers
        </a>
        , seat of
        <a href="/wiki/Glasgow_City_Council" title="Glasgow City Council">
         Glasgow City Council
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Historical subdivisions of Scotland included the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mormaerdom" title="Mormaerdom">
       mormaerdom
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stewartries" title="Stewartries">
       stewartry
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Earldom" title="Earldom">
       earldom
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Burgh" title="Burgh">
       burgh
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Civil_parishes_in_Scotland" title="Civil parishes in Scotland">
       parish
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Counties_of_Scotland" title="Counties of Scotland">
       county
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regions_and_districts_of_Scotland" title="Regions and districts of Scotland">
       regions and districts
      </a>
      . Some of these names are still sometimes used as geographical descriptors.
     </p>
     <p>
      Modern Scotland is subdivided in various ways depending on the purpose. In local government, there have been 32 single-tier council areas since 1996,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
       <a href="#cite_note-218">
        [218]
       </a>
      </sup>
      whose councils are responsible for the provision of all local government services. Community councils are informal organisations that represent specific sub-divisions of a council area.
     </p>
     <p>
      In the Scottish Parliament, there are 73 constituencies and eight regions. For the Parliament of the United Kingdom, there are 59 constituencies. Until 2013, the Scottish fire brigades and police forces were based on a system of regions introduced in 1975. For healthcare and postal districts, and a number of other governmental and non-governmental organisations such as the churches, there are other long-standing methods of subdividing Scotland for the purposes of administration.
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/City_status_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="City status in the United Kingdom">
       City status in the United Kingdom
      </a>
      is conferred by
      <a href="/wiki/Letters_patent" title="Letters patent">
       letters patent
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
       <a href="#cite_note-219">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are seven cities in Scotland:
      <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen" title="Aberdeen">
       Aberdeen
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Dundee" title="Dundee">
       Dundee
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">
       Edinburgh
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">
       Glasgow
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Inverness" title="Inverness">
       Inverness
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Stirling" title="Stirling">
       Stirling
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Perth,_Scotland" title="Perth, Scotland">
       Perth
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
       <a href="#cite_note-220">
        [220]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_criminal_justice">
       Law and criminal justice
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_law" title="Scots law">
       Scots law
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/170px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/255px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/340px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">
         High Court of Justiciary
        </a>
        , Edinburgh
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Scots law has a basis derived from
      <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">
       Roman law
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
       <a href="#cite_note-221">
        [221]
       </a>
      </sup>
      combining features of both uncodified
      <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">
       civil law
      </a>
      , dating back to the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Corpus_Juris_Civilis" title="Corpus Juris Civilis">
        Corpus Juris Civilis
       </a>
      </i>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">
       common law
      </a>
      with
      <a href="/wiki/Legal_institutions_of_Scotland_in_the_High_Middle_Ages" title="Legal institutions of Scotland in the High Middle Ages">
       medieval sources
      </a>
      . The terms of the Treaty of Union with England in 1707 guaranteed the continued existence of a separate legal system in Scotland from that of England and Wales.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
       <a href="#cite_note-222">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Prior to 1611, there were several regional law systems in Scotland, most notably
      <a href="/wiki/Udal_law" title="Udal law">
       Udal law
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Orkney" title="Orkney">
       Orkney
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Shetland" title="Shetland">
       Shetland
      </a>
      , based on old Norse law. Various other systems derived from common
      <a href="/wiki/Celtic_law" title="Celtic law">
       Celtic
      </a>
      or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brehon_laws" title="Brehon laws">
       Brehon laws
      </a>
      survived in the Highlands until the 1800s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
       <a href="#cite_note-223">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Scots law provides for three types of
      <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_Scotland" title="Courts of Scotland">
       courts
      </a>
      responsible for the administration of justice: civil, criminal and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Law_of_Arms" title="Law of Arms">
       heraldic
      </a>
      . The supreme civil court is the
      <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Session" title="Court of Session">
       Court of Session
      </a>
      , although civil
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Appeal_(law)" title="Appeal (law)">
       appeals
      </a>
      can be taken to the
      <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Supreme Court of the United Kingdom">
       Supreme Court of the United Kingdom
      </a>
      (or before 1 October 2009, the
      <a href="/wiki/Judicial_functions_of_the_House_of_Lords" title="Judicial functions of the House of Lords">
       House of Lords
      </a>
      ). The
      <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">
       High Court of Justiciary
      </a>
      is the supreme criminal court in Scotland. The Court of Session is housed at
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_House,_Edinburgh" title="Parliament House, Edinburgh">
       Parliament House
      </a>
      , in Edinburgh, which was the home of the pre-Union
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland" title="Parliament of Scotland">
       Parliament of Scotland
      </a>
      with the
      <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">
       High Court of Justiciary
      </a>
      and the Supreme Court of Appeal currently located at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lawnmarket" title="Lawnmarket">
       Lawnmarket
      </a>
      . The
      <a href="/wiki/Sheriff_court" title="Sheriff court">
       sheriff court
      </a>
      is the main criminal and civil court, hearing most cases. There are 49 sheriff courts throughout the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
       <a href="#cite_note-224">
        [224]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/District_Courts_of_Scotland" title="District Courts of Scotland">
       District courts
      </a>
      were introduced in 1975 for minor offences and small claims. These were gradually replaced by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Justice_of_the_Peace_Court" title="Justice of the Peace Court">
       Justice of the Peace Courts
      </a>
      from 2008 to 2010. The
      <a href="/wiki/Court_of_the_Lord_Lyon" title="Court of the Lord Lyon">
       Court of the Lord Lyon
      </a>
      regulates heraldry.
     </p>
     <p>
      For many decades the Scots legal system was unique for being the only legal system without a parliament. This ended with the advent of the Scottish Parliament, which legislates for Scotland. Many features within the system have been preserved. Within criminal law, the Scots legal system is unique in having three possible verdicts: "guilty", "not guilty" and "
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Not_proven" title="Not proven">
        not proven
       </a>
      </i>
      ".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
       <a href="#cite_note-225">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Both "not guilty" and "not proven" result in an
      <a href="/wiki/Acquittal" title="Acquittal">
       acquittal
      </a>
      , typically with no possibility of retrial in accordance with the rule of
      <a href="/wiki/Double_jeopardy" title="Double jeopardy">
       double jeopardy
      </a>
      . There is however the possibility of a retrial where new evidence emerges at a later date that might have proven conclusive in the earlier trial at first instance, where the person acquitted subsequently admits the offence or where it can be proved that the acquittal was tainted by an attempt to
      <a href="/wiki/Perverting_the_course_of_justice" title="Perverting the course of justice">
       pervert the course of justice
      </a>
      – see the provisions of the
      <a href="/wiki/Double_jeopardy#Scotland" title="Double jeopardy">
       Double Jeopardy (Scotland) Act 2011
      </a>
      . Many laws differ between Scotland and the other parts of the United Kingdom, and many terms differ for certain legal concepts.
      <a href="/wiki/Manslaughter" title="Manslaughter">
       Manslaughter
      </a>
      , in England and Wales, is broadly similar to
      <a href="/wiki/Culpable_homicide" title="Culpable homicide">
       culpable homicide
      </a>
      in Scotland, and arson is called
      <a href="/wiki/Wilful_fire_raising" title="Wilful fire raising">
       wilful fire raising
      </a>
      . Indeed, some acts considered crimes in England and Wales, such as forgery, are not so in Scotland. Procedure also differs. Scots juries, sitting in criminal cases, consist of fifteen, rather than twelve jurors, as is more common in English-speaking countries.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Prison_Service" title="Scottish Prison Service">
       Scottish Prison Service
      </a>
      (SPS) manages the prisons in Scotland, which collectively house over 8,500 prisoners.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
       <a href="#cite_note-226">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_Secretary_for_Justice" title="Cabinet Secretary for Justice">
       Cabinet Secretary for Justice
      </a>
      is responsible for the Scottish Prison Service within the Scottish Government.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">
       Health care
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Scotland" title="Healthcare in Scotland">
       Healthcare in Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:QEUH2.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2988" data-file-width="5113" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/QEUH2.jpg/220px-QEUH2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/QEUH2.jpg/330px-QEUH2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/QEUH2.jpg/440px-QEUH2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:QEUH2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/NHS_Scotland" title="NHS Scotland">
         NHS Scotland
        </a>
        's
        <a href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_University_Hospital" title="Queen Elizabeth University Hospital">
         Queen Elizabeth University Hospital
        </a>
        , Glasgow
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Healthcare in Scotland is mainly provided by
      <a href="/wiki/NHS_Scotland" title="NHS Scotland">
       NHS Scotland
      </a>
      , Scotland's public health care system. This was founded by the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service_(Scotland)_Act_1947" title="National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1947">
       National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1947
      </a>
      (later repealed by the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978) that took effect on 5 July 1948 to coincide with the launch of the NHS in England and Wales. However, even prior to 1948, half of Scotland's landmass was already covered by state funded health care, provided by the
      <a href="/wiki/Highlands_and_Islands_Medical_Service" title="Highlands and Islands Medical Service">
       Highlands and Islands Medical Service
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
       <a href="#cite_note-227">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Healthcare policy and funding is the responsibility of the Scottish Government's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Government_Health_Directorates" title="Scottish Government Health Directorates">
       Health Directorates
      </a>
      . The current
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabinet_Secretary_for_Health_and_Wellbeing" title="Cabinet Secretary for Health and Wellbeing">
       Cabinet Secretary for Health and Wellbeing
      </a>
      is
      <a href="/wiki/Alex_Neil_(politician)" title="Alex Neil (politician)">
       Alex Neil
      </a>
      and the Director-General (DG) Health and chief executive, NHS Scotland is Paul Gray.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
       <a href="#cite_note-228">
        [228]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2008, the NHS in Scotland had around 158,000 staff including more than 47,500 nurses, midwives and health visitors and over 3,800 consultants. In addition, there are also more than 12,000 doctors, family practitioners and allied health professionals, including dentists, opticians and community pharmacists, who operate as independent contractors providing a range of services within the NHS in return for fees and allowances. These fees and allowances were removed in May 2010, and prescriptions are entirely free, although dentists and opticians may charge if the patient's household earns over a certain amount, about £30,000 per annum.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
       <a href="#cite_note-229">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
       Economy
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Scotland" title="Economy of Scotland">
       Economy of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2560" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg/220px-Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg/330px-Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg/440px-Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Drilling_rig" title="Drilling rig">
         drilling rig
        </a>
        located in the
        <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">
         North Sea
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Scotland has a Western-style
      <a href="/wiki/Open_economy" title="Open economy">
       open
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">
       mixed economy
      </a>
      closely linked with the rest of Europe and the wider world. Traditionally, the Scottish economy has been dominated by
      <a href="/wiki/Heavy_industry" title="Heavy industry">
       heavy industry
      </a>
      underpinned by shipbuilding in Glasgow, coal mining and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Steel_making" title="Steel making">
       steel industries
      </a>
      . Petroleum related industries associated with the extraction of
      <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">
       North Sea oil
      </a>
      have also been important employers from the 1970s, especially in the north-east of Scotland.
     </p>
     <p>
      In February 2012, the Centre for Economics and Business Research concluded that "Scotland receives no net subsidy" from the UK, as greater per capita tax generation in Scotland balanced out greater per capita public spending.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
      More recent data, from 2012–13, show that Scotland generated 9.1% (£53.1bn; this included a geographical share of North Sea oil revenue – without it, the figures were 8.2% and £47.6bn) of the UK's tax revenues and received 9.3% (£65.2bn) of spending.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
       <a href="#cite_note-231">
        [231]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland's public spending deficit in 2012–13 was £12bn, a £3.5bn increase on the previous year; over the same period, the UK's deficit decreased by £2.6bn.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Over the past thirty years, Scotland contributed a relative budget surplus
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
         <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (January 2014)">
          clarification needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      of almost £20billion to the UK economy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
       <a href="#cite_note-233">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the third quarter of 2015, the Scottish economy grew by 0.1%, below the 0.4% recorded for the UK.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1.0_234-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-1.0-234">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of September 2015, the Scottish unemployment rate of 5.9% was above the UK rate of 5.5%, while the Scottish employment rate of 74.0% was higher than the UK figure of 73.5%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
       <a href="#cite_note-235">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      De-industrialisation during the 1970s and 1980s saw a shift from a manufacturing focus towards a more
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_economic_activity" title="Tertiary sector of economic activity">
       service
      </a>
      -oriented economy.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1008" data-file-width="1606" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg/220px-QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg/330px-QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg/440px-QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:QE2_Clyde_5_Oct_08_1154.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Scotland's shipbuilding industry produces world-class ships, including
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_2" title="Queen Elizabeth 2">
          Queen Elizabeth 2
         </a>
        </i>
        (pictured)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Edinburgh is the financial services centre of Scotland, with many large finance firms based there, including:
      <a href="/wiki/Lloyds_Banking_Group" title="Lloyds Banking Group">
       Lloyds Banking Group
      </a>
      (owners of
      <a href="/wiki/HBOS" title="HBOS">
       HBOS
      </a>
      ); the Government owned
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Bank_of_Scotland" title="Royal Bank of Scotland">
       Royal Bank of Scotland
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Standard_Life" title="Standard Life">
       Standard Life
      </a>
      . Edinburgh was ranked 15th in the
      <a href="/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index" title="Global Financial Centres Index">
       list of world financial centres
      </a>
      in 2007, but fell to 37th in 2012, following damage to its reputation,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and in 2016 was ranked 56th out of 86.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
       <a href="#cite_note-237">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2012, total Scottish exports (excluding intra-UK trade) were estimated to be £26 billion, of which 59% (£15.4 billion) were attributable to manufacturing.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trade_238-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Trade-238">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland's primary exports include
      <a href="/wiki/Whisky" title="Whisky">
       whisky
      </a>
      , electronics and financial services. The United States, Netherlands, Germany, France and Norway constitute the country's major export markets.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trade_238-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Trade-238">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland's Gross Domestic Product (GDP), including oil and gas produced in Scottish waters, was estimated at £150 billion for the calendar year 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_9-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GDP-9">
        [9]
       </a>
      </sup>
      If Scotland became independent, it would hold 95% of the UK's current oil and gas reserves if they were split geographically using a median line from the English-Scottish border.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2014)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      If the reserves were split by population, that figure would be reduced to 9%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Whisky is one of Scotland's more known goods of economic activity. Exports increased by 87% in the decade to 2012
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and were valued at £4.3 billion in 2013, which was 85% of Scotland's food and drink exports.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
       <a href="#cite_note-241">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It supports around 10,000 jobs directly and 25,000 indirectly.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
       <a href="#cite_note-242">
        [242]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It may contribute £400–682 million to Scotland, rather than several billion pounds, as more than 80% of whisky produced is owned by non-Scottish companies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
       <a href="#cite_note-243">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A briefing published in 2002 by the Scottish Parliament Information Centre (SPICe) for the Scottish Parliament's Enterprise and Life Long Learning Committee stated that tourism accounted for up to 5% of GDP and 7.5% of employment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
       <a href="#cite_note-244">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Currency">
       Currency
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RoyBankScotland100.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="130" data-file-width="455" height="57" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e0/RoyBankScotland100.jpg/200px-RoyBankScotland100.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e0/RoyBankScotland100.jpg/300px-RoyBankScotland100.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e0/RoyBankScotland100.jpg/400px-RoyBankScotland100.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RoyBankScotland100.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A £100 Sterling
        <a href="/wiki/Royal_Bank_of_Scotland" title="Royal Bank of Scotland">
         RBS
        </a>
        note.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Banknotes_of_the_pound_sterling#Scotland" title="Banknotes of the pound sterling">
       Banknotes of the pound sterling § Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Although the
      <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">
       Bank of England
      </a>
      is the
      <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">
       central bank
      </a>
      for the UK, three Scottish
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Clearing_banks" title="Clearing banks">
       clearing banks
      </a>
      issue
      <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">
       Sterling
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Banknote" title="Banknote">
       banknotes
      </a>
      : the
      <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Scotland" title="Bank of Scotland">
       Bank of Scotland
      </a>
      ; the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Bank_of_Scotland" title="Royal Bank of Scotland">
       Royal Bank of Scotland
      </a>
      ; and the
      <a href="/wiki/Clydesdale_Bank" title="Clydesdale Bank">
       Clydesdale Bank
      </a>
      . The value of the Scottish banknotes in circulation in 2013 was £3.8 billion; underwritten by the Bank of England using funds deposited by each clearing bank, under the
      <a href="/wiki/Banking_Act_2009" title="Banking Act 2009">
       Banking Act, (2009)
      </a>
      , in order to cover the total value of such notes in circulation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Banknotes_245-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Banknotes-245">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">
       Military
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Scotland" title="Military of Scotland">
       Military of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2580" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg/220px-Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg/330px-Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg/440px-Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Challenger2-Bergen-Hohne-Training-Area-2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Challenger_2" title="Challenger 2">
         Challenger 2
        </a>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Main_Battle_Tank" title="Main Battle Tank">
         Main Battle Tank
        </a>
        of the
        <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scots_Dragoon_Guards" title="Royal Scots Dragoon Guards">
         Royal Scots Dragoon Guards
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Of the money spent on UK defence, about £3.3 billion can be attributed to Scotland as of 2013. Although Scotland has a long military tradition predating the
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">
       Treaty of Union
      </a>
      with England, its armed forces now form part of the
      <a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">
       British Armed Forces
      </a>
      , with the notable exception of the
      <a href="/wiki/Atholl_Highlanders" title="Atholl Highlanders">
       Atholl Highlanders
      </a>
      , Europe's only legal private army. In 2006, the infantry regiments of the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Division" title="Scottish Division">
       Scottish Division
      </a>
      were amalgamated to form the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Regiment_of_Scotland" title="Royal Regiment of Scotland">
       Royal Regiment of Scotland
      </a>
      . Other distinctively Scottish regiments in the British Army include the
      <a href="/wiki/Scots_Guards" title="Scots Guards">
       Scots Guards
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scots_Dragoon_Guards" title="Royal Scots Dragoon Guards">
       Royal Scots Dragoon Guards
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Transport_Regiment" title="Scottish Transport Regiment">
       Scottish Transport Regiment
      </a>
      , a Territorial Army Regiment of the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Logistic_Corps" title="Royal Logistic Corps">
       Royal Logistic Corps
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Because of their topography and perceived remoteness, parts of Scotland have housed many sensitive defence establishments.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
       <a href="#cite_note-246">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
       <a href="#cite_note-247">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
       <a href="#cite_note-248">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Between 1960 and 1991, the
      <a href="/wiki/Holy_Loch" title="Holy Loch">
       Holy Loch
      </a>
      was a base for the US fleet of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polaris_ballistic_missile" title="Polaris ballistic missile">
       Polaris
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">
       ballistic missile submarines
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
       <a href="#cite_note-249">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Today, Her Majesty's Naval Base
      <a href="/wiki/HMNB_Clyde" title="HMNB Clyde">
       Clyde
      </a>
      , 25 miles (40 kilometres) north-west of Glasgow, is the base for the four
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trident_missiles" title="Trident missiles">
       Trident
      </a>
      -armed
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vanguard_class_submarine" title="Vanguard class submarine">
       <i>
        Vanguard
       </i>
       class
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">
       ballistic missile submarines
      </a>
      that comprise the
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_the_United_Kingdom" title="Nuclear weapons and the United Kingdom">
       UK's nuclear deterrent
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Scapa_Flow" title="Scapa Flow">
       Scapa Flow
      </a>
      was the major
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Grand_Fleet" title="British Grand Fleet">
       Fleet
      </a>
      base for the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">
       Royal Navy
      </a>
      until 1956.
     </p>
     <p>
      A single front-line
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">
       Royal Air Force
      </a>
      base is located in Scotland.
      <a href="/wiki/RAF_Lossiemouth" title="RAF Lossiemouth">
       RAF Lossiemouth
      </a>
      , located in
      <a href="/wiki/Moray" title="Moray">
       Moray
      </a>
      , is the most northerly air defence
      <a href="/wiki/Fighter_aircraft" title="Fighter aircraft">
       fighter
      </a>
      base in the United Kingdom and is home to
      <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter_Typhoon" title="Eurofighter Typhoon">
       Typhoon
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Panavia_Tornado" title="Panavia Tornado">
       Tornado
      </a>
      fast-jet squadrons
     </p>
     <p>
      The only open-air live
      <a href="/wiki/Depleted_uranium" title="Depleted uranium">
       depleted uranium
      </a>
      weapons test range in the British Isles is located near
      <a href="/wiki/Dundrennan_Range" title="Dundrennan Range">
       Dundrennan
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
       <a href="#cite_note-250">
        [250]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a result, over 7000 potentially toxic munitions lie on the seabed of the
      <a href="/wiki/Solway_Firth" title="Solway Firth">
       Solway Firth
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
       <a href="#cite_note-251">
        [251]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_252-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-252">
        [252]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Education_2">
       Education
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">
       Education in Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UWS,_Ayr_Campus.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="582" data-file-width="710" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/UWS%2C_Ayr_Campus.jpg/220px-UWS%2C_Ayr_Campus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/UWS%2C_Ayr_Campus.jpg/330px-UWS%2C_Ayr_Campus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/UWS%2C_Ayr_Campus.jpg/440px-UWS%2C_Ayr_Campus.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UWS,_Ayr_Campus.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_West_of_Scotland" title="University of the West of Scotland">
         University of the West of Scotland
        </a>
        , Ayr Campus
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Scottish education system is distinct from the rest of the United Kingdom. The "
      <a href="/wiki/Curriculum_for_Excellence" title="Curriculum for Excellence">
       Curriculum for Excellence
      </a>
      " provides the curricular framework for children and young people from age 3 to 18.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
       <a href="#cite_note-253">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
      All 3- and 4-year-old children in Scotland are entitled to a free nursery place. Formal primary education begins at approximately 5 years old and lasts for 7 years (P1–P7); today, children in Scotland study
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_Grades" title="Standard Grades">
       Standard Grades
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Intermediate_1" title="Intermediate 1">
       Intermediate
      </a>
      qualifications between the ages of 14 and 16. These are being phased out and replaced by the National Qualifications of the
      <a href="/wiki/Curriculum_for_Excellence" title="Curriculum for Excellence">
       Curriculum for Excellence
      </a>
      . The school leaving age is 16, after which students may choose to remain at school and study for
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Access_exams" title="Access exams">
       Access
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intermediate_exams" title="Intermediate exams">
       Intermediate
      </a>
      or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Higher_Grade" title="Higher Grade">
       Higher Grade
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Advanced_Higher_(Scottish)" title="Advanced Higher (Scottish)">
       Advanced Higher
      </a>
      qualifications. A small number of students at certain private,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Independent_school_(UK)" title="Independent school (UK)">
       independent schools
      </a>
      may follow the
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_England" title="Education in England">
       English system
      </a>
      and study towards
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GCSE" title="GCSE">
       GCSEs
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Advanced_Level_(UK)" title="Advanced Level (UK)">
       A
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Advanced_Level_(UK)" title="Advanced Level (UK)">
       AS-Levels
      </a>
      instead.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
       <a href="#cite_note-254">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There are fifteen
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_universities" title="Scottish universities">
       Scottish universities
      </a>
      , some of which are amongst the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_oldest_universities_in_continuous_operation" title="List of oldest universities in continuous operation">
       oldest in the world
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        [256]
       </a>
      </sup>
      These include the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_St_Andrews" title="University of St Andrews">
       University of St Andrews
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Glasgow" title="University of Glasgow">
       University of Glasgow
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Aberdeen" title="University of Aberdeen">
       University of Aberdeen
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh" title="University of Edinburgh">
       University of Edinburgh
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Dundee" title="University of Dundee">
       University of Dundee
      </a>
      —many of which are ranked amongst the best in the UK.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
       <a href="#cite_note-257">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
       <a href="#cite_note-258">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Proportionally, Scotland has more universities in
      <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">
       QS' World University Rankings'
      </a>
      top 100 than any other nation in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
       <a href="#cite_note-259">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country produces 1% of the world's
      <a href="/wiki/Academic_publishing" title="Academic publishing">
       published research
      </a>
      with less than 0.1% of the world's population, and higher education institutions account for 9% of Scotland's service sector exports.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
       <a href="#cite_note-260">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
       <a href="#cite_note-261">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland's University Courts are the only bodies in Scotland authorised to award degrees. Scotland's Universities are complemented in the provision of Further and Higher Education by 43 Colleges. Colleges offer National Certificates, Higher National Certificates and Higher National Diplomas. These Group Awards, alongside Scottish Vocational Qualifications, aim to ensure Scotland's population has the appropriate skills and knowledge to meet workplace needs.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2014, research reported by the
      <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">
       Office for National Statistics
      </a>
      found that Scotland was the most highly educated country in Europe and among the most well-educated in the world in terms of tertiary education attainment, with roughly 40% of people in Scotland aged 16–64 educated to
      <a href="/wiki/National_Vocational_Qualification#Levels" title="National Vocational Qualification">
       NVQ level 4
      </a>
      and above.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
       <a href="#cite_note-262">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Based on the original data for
      <a href="/wiki/Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics" title="Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics">
       EU statistical regions
      </a>
      , all four Scottish regions ranked significantly above the European average for completion of tertiary-level education by 25- to 64-year-olds.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurostat_263-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Eurostat-263">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
       Culture
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Scotland" title="Culture of Scotland">
       Culture of Scotland
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Scotland" title="National symbols of Scotland">
       National symbols of Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_people" title="Scottish people">
       Scottish people
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Scotland" title="Music of Scotland">
       Music of Scotland
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_literature" title="Scottish literature">
       Scottish literature
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_art" title="Scottish art">
       Scottish art
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Scotland" title="Media of Scotland">
       Media of Scotland
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_cuisine" title="Scottish cuisine">
       Scottish cuisine
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bagpipe_performer.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="964" data-file-width="400" height="410" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Bagpipe_performer.jpg/170px-Bagpipe_performer.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Bagpipe_performer.jpg/255px-Bagpipe_performer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Bagpipe_performer.jpg/340px-Bagpipe_performer.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bagpipe_performer.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A Pipe Major playing the
        <a href="/wiki/Great_Highland_Bagpipe" title="Great Highland Bagpipe">
         Great Highland Bagpipe
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_music" title="Scottish music">
       Scottish music
      </a>
      is a significant aspect of the nation's culture, with both traditional and modern influences. A famous traditional Scottish instrument is the
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Highland_Bagpipe" title="Great Highland Bagpipe">
       Great Highland Bagpipe
      </a>
      , a wind instrument consisting of three drones and a melody pipe (called the chanter), which are fed continuously by a reservoir of air in a bag.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pipe_Band" title="Pipe Band">
       Bagpipe bands
      </a>
      , featuring bagpipes and various types of drums, and showcasing Scottish music styles while creating new ones, have spread throughout the world. The
      <a href="/wiki/Cl%C3%A0rsach" title="Clàrsach">
       clàrsach
      </a>
      (harp),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Musical_styles_(violin)#Fiddle" title="Musical styles (violin)">
       fiddle
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Accordion" title="Accordion">
       accordion
      </a>
      are also traditional Scottish instruments, the latter two heavily featured in
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_country_dance" title="Scottish country dance">
       Scottish country dance
      </a>
      bands. Today, there are many successful Scottish bands and individual artists in varying styles including
      <a href="/wiki/Annie_Lennox" title="Annie Lennox">
       Annie Lennox
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Amy_Macdonald" title="Amy Macdonald">
       Amy Macdonald
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Runrig" title="Runrig">
       Runrig
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Boards_of_Canada" title="Boards of Canada">
       Boards of Canada
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cocteau_Twins" title="Cocteau Twins">
       Cocteau Twins
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Deacon_Blue" title="Deacon Blue">
       Deacon Blue
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Franz_Ferdinand_(band)" title="Franz Ferdinand (band)">
       Franz Ferdinand
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Susan_Boyle" title="Susan Boyle">
       Susan Boyle
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Emeli_Sand%C3%A9" title="Emeli Sandé">
       Emeli Sandé
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Texas_(band)" title="Texas (band)">
       Texas
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/The_View_(band)" title="The View (band)">
       The View
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/The_Fratellis" title="The Fratellis">
       The Fratellis
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Twin_Atlantic" title="Twin Atlantic">
       Twin Atlantic
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Biffy_Clyro" title="Biffy Clyro">
       Biffy Clyro
      </a>
      . Other Scottish musicians include
      <a href="/wiki/Shirley_Manson" title="Shirley Manson">
       Shirley Manson
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Nutini" title="Paolo Nutini">
       Paolo Nutini
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Calvin_Harris" title="Calvin Harris">
       Calvin Harris
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
       <a href="#cite_note-264">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Scotland has a literary heritage dating back to the early Middle Ages. The earliest extant literature composed in what is now Scotland was in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brythonic_languages" title="Brythonic languages">
       Brythonic
      </a>
      speech in the 6th century, but is preserved as part of
      <a href="/wiki/Welsh-language_literature" title="Welsh-language literature">
       Welsh literature
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Later medieval literature included works in Latin,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Gaelic,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
       <a href="#cite_note-267">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Old English
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and French.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first surviving major text in
      <a href="/wiki/Early_Scots" title="Early Scots">
       Early Scots
      </a>
      is the 14th-century poet
      <a href="/wiki/John_Barbour_(poet)" title="John Barbour (poet)">
       John Barbour
      </a>
      's epic
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Brus" title="The Brus">
        Brus
       </a>
      </i>
      , focusing on the life of Robert I,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
       <a href="#cite_note-270">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and was soon followed by a series of vernacular romances and prose works.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wormald1991pp60-7_271-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wormald1991pp60-7-271">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 16th century the crown's patronage helped the development of Scots drama and poetry,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brownetalpp256-7_272-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Brownetalpp256-7-272">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but the accession of James VI to the English throne removed a major centre of literary patronage and Scots was sidelined as a literary language.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        [273]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Interest in Scots literature was revived in the 18th century by figures including
      <a href="/wiki/James_Macpherson" title="James Macpherson">
       James Macpherson
      </a>
      , whose
      <a href="/wiki/Ossian" title="Ossian">
       Ossian Cycle
      </a>
      made him the first Scottish poet to gain an international reputation and was a major influence on the European Enlightenment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
       <a href="#cite_note-274">
        [274]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was also a major influence on
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Burns" title="Robert Burns">
       Robert Burns
      </a>
      , whom many consider the national poet,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
       <a href="#cite_note-275">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">
       Walter Scott
      </a>
      , whose
      <a href="/wiki/Waverley_Novels" title="Waverley Novels">
       Waverley Novels
      </a>
      did much to define Scottish identity in the 19th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
       <a href="#cite_note-276">
        [276]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Towards the end of the Victorian era a number of Scottish-born authors achieved international reputations as writers in English, including
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson" title="Robert Louis Stevenson">
       Robert Louis Stevenson
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle">
       Arthur Conan Doyle
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/J._M._Barrie" title="J. M. Barrie">
       J. M. Barrie
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/George_MacDonald" title="George MacDonald">
       George MacDonald
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
       <a href="#cite_note-277">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 20th century the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Renaissance" title="Scottish Renaissance">
       Scottish Renaissance
      </a>
      saw a surge of literary activity and attempts to reclaim the Scots language as a medium for serious literature.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VisitingArtsScotland_278-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-VisitingArtsScotland-278">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Members of the movement were followed by a new generation of post-war poets including
      <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Morgan_(poet)" title="Edwin Morgan (poet)">
       Edwin Morgan
      </a>
      , who would be appointed the first
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scots_Makar" title="Scots Makar">
       Scots Makar
      </a>
      by the inaugural Scottish government in 2004.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
       <a href="#cite_note-279">
        [279]
       </a>
      </sup>
      From the 1980s Scottish literature enjoyed another major revival, particularly associated with a group of writers including
      <a href="/wiki/Irvine_Welsh" title="Irvine Welsh">
       Irvine Welsh
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VisitingArtsScotland_278-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-VisitingArtsScotland-278">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scottish poets who emerged in the same period included
      <a href="/wiki/Carol_Ann_Duffy" title="Carol Ann Duffy">
       Carol Ann Duffy
      </a>
      , who, in May 2009, was the first Scot named UK
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poet_Laureate" title="Poet Laureate">
       Poet Laureate
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
       <a href="#cite_note-280">
        [280]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      As one of the
      <a href="/wiki/Celtic_nations" title="Celtic nations">
       Celtic nations
      </a>
      , Scotland and Scottish culture is represented at interceltic events at home and over the world. Scotland hosts several music festivals including
      <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Connections" title="Celtic Connections">
       Celtic Connections
      </a>
      (Glasgow), and the
      <a href="/wiki/Hebridean_Celtic_Festival" title="Hebridean Celtic Festival">
       Hebridean Celtic Festival
      </a>
      (Stornoway). Festivals celebrating Celtic culture, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Festival_Interceltique_de_Lorient" title="Festival Interceltique de Lorient">
       Festival Interceltique de Lorient
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Brittany" title="Brittany">
       Brittany
      </a>
      ), the
      <a href="/wiki/Pan_Celtic_Festival" title="Pan Celtic Festival">
       Pan Celtic Festival
      </a>
      (Ireland), and the National Celtic Festival (
      <a href="/wiki/Portarlington,_Victoria" title="Portarlington, Victoria">
       Portarlington
      </a>
      , Australia), feature elements of Scottish culture such as language, music and dance.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Celtic_nation_1_281-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Celtic_nation_1-281">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Celtic_nation_2_282-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Celtic_nation_2-282">
        [282]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Celtic_connections_1_283-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Celtic_connections_1-283">
        [283]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hebridean_Celtic_1_284-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Hebridean_Celtic_1-284">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Festival_1_285-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Festival_1-285">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dingle_1_286-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dingle_1-286">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Festival_3_287-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Festival_3-287">
        [287]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2546" data-file-width="1849" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG/170px-Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG/255px-Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG/340px-Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Carving_of_Saint_Andrew.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Saint Andrew depicted on a 16th-century coat of arms of the burgh of
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Andrews" title="St. Andrews">
         St. Andrews
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The image of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Andrew" title="Saint Andrew">
       St. Andrew
      </a>
      , martyred while bound to an X-shaped cross, first appeared in the
      <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland" title="Kingdom of Scotland">
       Kingdom of Scotland
      </a>
      during the reign of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/William_I_of_Scotland" title="William I of Scotland">
       William I
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NAS_288-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NAS-288">
        [288]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following the death of
      <a href="/wiki/Alexander_III_of_Scotland" title="Alexander III of Scotland">
       King Alexander III
      </a>
      in 1286 an image of Andrew was used on the
      <a href="/wiki/Seal_(emblem)" title="Seal (emblem)">
       seal
      </a>
      of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guardians_of_Scotland" title="Guardians of Scotland">
       Guardians of Scotland
      </a>
      who assumed control of the kingdom during the subsequent
      <a href="/wiki/Interregnum" title="Interregnum">
       interregnum
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_289-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-289">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Use of a simplified symbol associated with Saint Andrew, the
      <a href="/wiki/Saltire" title="Saltire">
       saltire
      </a>
      , has its origins in the late 14th century; the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland" title="Parliament of Scotland">
       Parliament of Scotland
      </a>
      decreeing in 1385 that Scottish soldiers should wear a white Saint Andrew's Cross on the front and back of their tunics.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
       <a href="#cite_note-290">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Use of a blue background for the Saint Andrew's Cross is said to date from at least the 15th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
       <a href="#cite_note-291">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since 1606 the saltire has also formed part of the design of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Union_Flag" title="Union Flag">
       Union Flag
      </a>
      . There are numerous other symbols and symbolic artefacts, both official and unofficial, including the
      <a href="/wiki/Thistle" title="Thistle">
       thistle
      </a>
      , the nation's
      <a href="/wiki/National_emblem" title="National emblem">
       floral emblem
      </a>
      (celebrated in the song,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Thistle_o%27_Scotland_(song)" title="The Thistle o' Scotland (song)">
       The Thistle o' Scotland
      </a>
      ), the
      <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Arbroath" title="Declaration of Arbroath">
       Declaration of Arbroath
      </a>
      , incorporating a statement of political independence made on 6 April 1320, the textile pattern
      <a href="/wiki/Tartan" title="Tartan">
       tartan
      </a>
      that often signifies a particular
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_clan" title="Scottish clan">
       Scottish clan
      </a>
      and the royal
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_Standard_of_Scotland" title="Royal Standard of Scotland">
       Lion Rampant
      </a>
      flag.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
       <a href="#cite_note-292">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
       <a href="#cite_note-293">
        [293]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
       <a href="#cite_note-294">
        [294]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Highlanders can thank
      <a href="/wiki/James_Graham,_3rd_Duke_of_Montrose" title="James Graham, 3rd Duke of Montrose">
       James Graham, 3rd Duke of Montrose
      </a>
      , for the repeal in 1782 of the Act of 1747 prohibiting the wearing of tartans.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Works_295-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Works-295">
        [295]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Although there is no official
      <a href="/wiki/National_anthem_of_Scotland" title="National anthem of Scotland">
       national anthem of Scotland
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
       <a href="#cite_note-296">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Flower_of_Scotland" title="Flower of Scotland">
        Flower of Scotland
       </a>
      </i>
      is played on special occasions and sporting events such as football and rugby matches involving the Scotland national teams and since 2010 is also played at the Commonwealth Games after it was voted the overwhelming favourite by participating Scottish athletes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
       <a href="#cite_note-297">
        [297]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other currently less popular candidates for the National Anthem of Scotland include
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Scotland_the_Brave" title="Scotland the Brave">
        Scotland the Brave
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Highland_Cathedral" title="Highland Cathedral">
        Highland Cathedral
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Scots_Wha_Hae" title="Scots Wha Hae">
        Scots Wha Hae
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A_Man%27s_A_Man_for_A%27_That" title="A Man's A Man for A' That">
        A Man's A Man for A' That
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St_Andrew%27s_Day" title="St Andrew's Day">
       St Andrew's Day
      </a>
      , 30 November, is the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_day" title="National day">
       national day
      </a>
      , although
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Burns%27_Night" title="Burns' Night">
       Burns' Night
      </a>
      tends to be more widely observed, particularly outside Scotland. In 2006, the Scottish Parliament passed the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Andrew%27s_Day_Bank_Holiday_(Scotland)_Act_2007" title="St. Andrew's Day Bank Holiday (Scotland) Act 2007">
       St. Andrew's Day Bank Holiday (Scotland) Act 2007
      </a>
      , designating the day an official
      <a href="/wiki/Bank_holiday" title="Bank holiday">
       bank holiday
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
       <a href="#cite_note-298">
        [298]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Tartan_Day" title="Tartan Day">
       Tartan Day
      </a>
      is a recent innovation from Canada.
     </p>
     <p>
      The national animal of Scotland is the
      <a href="/wiki/Unicorn" title="Unicorn">
       unicorn
      </a>
      , which has been a Scottish heraldic symbol since the 12th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
       <a href="#cite_note-299">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
       Media
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5397" data-file-width="3918" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg/170px-John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg/255px-John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg/340px-John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_Logie_Baird_in_1917.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Scottish inventor
        <a href="/wiki/John_Logie_Baird" title="John Logie Baird">
         John Logie Baird
        </a>
        demonstrated the first working television system on 26 January 1926.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
         <a href="#cite_note-300">
          [300]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      National newspapers such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Daily_Record_(Scotland)" title="Daily Record (Scotland)">
       <i>
        Daily Record
       </i>
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/The_Herald_(Glasgow)" title="The Herald (Glasgow)">
       <i>
        The Herald
       </i>
      </a>
      , and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Scotsman" title="The Scotsman">
        The Scotsman
       </a>
      </i>
      are all produced in Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newspapers_301-0">
