       <a href="#cite_note-Newspapers-301">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Important regional dailies include the
      <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Evening_News" title="Edinburgh Evening News">
       Evening News
      </a>
      in Edinburgh
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Courier_and_Advertiser" title="The Courier and Advertiser">
        The Courier
       </a>
      </i>
      in Dundee in the east, and
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Press_and_Journal_(Scotland)" title="Press and Journal (Scotland)">
        The Press and Journal
       </a>
      </i>
      serving Aberdeen and the north.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Newspapers_301-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Newspapers-301">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland is represented at the
      <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Media_Festival" title="Celtic Media Festival">
       Celtic Media Festival
      </a>
      , which showcases film and television from the Celtic countries. Scottish entrants have won many awards since the festival began in 1980.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Media_1_302-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Media_1-302">
        [302]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Television in Scotland is largely the same as UK-wide broadcasts, however the national broadcaster is
      <a href="/wiki/BBC_Scotland" title="BBC Scotland">
       BBC Scotland
      </a>
      , a constituent part of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="British Broadcasting Corporation">
       British Broadcasting Corporation
      </a>
      , the publicly funded broadcaster of the United Kingdom. It runs three national
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_television_stations" title="Scottish television stations">
       television stations
      </a>
      , and the national radio stations,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_Scotland" title="BBC Radio Scotland">
        BBC Radio Scotland
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_nan_Gaidheal" title="BBC Radio nan Gaidheal">
        BBC Radio nan Gaidheal
       </a>
      </i>
      , amongst others. Scotland also has some programming in the Gaelic language.
      <a href="/wiki/BBC_Alba" title="BBC Alba">
       BBC Alba
      </a>
      is the national Gaelic-language channel. The main Scottish commercial television station is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/STV_(TV_network)" title="STV (TV network)">
       STV
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">
       Sport
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Scotland" title="Sport in Scotland">
       Sport in Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="640" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg/220px-18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg/330px-18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg/440px-18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:18th_Green_and_Clubhouse.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Old_Course_at_St_Andrews" title="Old Course at St Andrews">
         Old Course at St Andrews
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Scotland hosts its own national sporting competitions and has independent representation at several international sporting events, including the
      <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">
       FIFA World Cup
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rugby_Union_World_Cup" title="Rugby Union World Cup">
       Rugby Union World Cup
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_League_World_Cup" title="Rugby League World Cup">
       Rugby League World Cup
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">
       Cricket World Cup
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Netball_World_Cup" title="Netball World Cup">
       Netball World Cup
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Games" title="Commonwealth Games">
       Commonwealth Games
      </a>
      . Scotland has its own national governing bodies, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Football_Association" title="Scottish Football Association">
       Scottish Football Association
      </a>
      (the second oldest national football association in the world)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
       <a href="#cite_note-303">
        [303]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Rugby_Union" title="Scottish Rugby Union">
       Scottish Rugby Union
      </a>
      . Variations of football have been played in Scotland for centuries, with the earliest reference dating back to 1424.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FIFA_304-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FIFA-304">
        [304]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Association football is the most popular sport and the
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Cup" title="Scottish Cup">
       Scottish Cup
      </a>
      is the world's oldest national trophy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trophy_305-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Trophy-305">
        [305]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Scotland contested the first ever international
      <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
       football
      </a>
      game in 1872 against England.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
       <a href="#cite_note-306">
        [306]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The match took place at
      <a href="/wiki/Hamilton_Crescent" title="Hamilton Crescent">
       Hamilton Crescent
      </a>
      , Glasgow, home of the
      <a href="/wiki/West_of_Scotland_Cricket_Club" title="West of Scotland Cricket Club">
       West of Scotland Cricket Club
      </a>
      . Scottish clubs have been successful in European competitions with
      <a href="/wiki/Celtic_F.C." title="Celtic F.C.">
       Celtic
      </a>
      winning the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Champion_Clubs%27_Cup" title="European Champion Clubs' Cup">
       European Cup
      </a>
      in 1967,
      <a href="/wiki/Rangers_F.C." title="Rangers F.C.">
       Rangers
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen_F.C." title="Aberdeen F.C.">
       Aberdeen
      </a>
      winning the
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup" title="UEFA Cup Winners' Cup">
       UEFA Cup Winners' Cup
      </a>
      in 1972 and 1983 respectively, and Aberdeen also winning the
      <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Super_Cup" title="UEFA Super Cup">
       UEFA Super Cup
      </a>
      in 1983.
     </p>
     <p>
      With the modern game of
      <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">
       golf
      </a>
      originating in 15th century Scotland, the country is promoted as the
      <a href="/wiki/Golf_in_Scotland" title="Golf in Scotland">
       home of golf
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
       <a href="#cite_note-307">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
       <a href="#cite_note-308">
        [308]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
       <a href="#cite_note-309">
        [309]
       </a>
      </sup>
      To many golfers the
      <a href="/wiki/Old_Course_at_St_Andrews" title="Old Course at St Andrews">
       Old Course
      </a>
      in the Fife town of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Andrews" title="St. Andrews">
       St. Andrews
      </a>
      , an ancient
      <a href="/wiki/Links_(golf)" title="Links (golf)">
       links
      </a>
      course dating to before 1574, is considered a site of pilgrimage.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
       <a href="#cite_note-310">
        [310]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1764, the standard 18-hole golf course was created at St Andrews when members modified the course from 22 to 18 holes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
       <a href="#cite_note-311">
        [311]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The world's oldest golf tournament, and golf's first major, is
      <a href="/wiki/The_Open_Championship" title="The Open Championship">
       The Open Championship
      </a>
      , which was first played on 17 October 1860 at Prestwick Golf Club, in Ayrshire, Scotland, with
      <a href="/wiki/Men%27s_major_golf_championships#Major_championship_winners" title="Men's major golf championships">
       Scottish golfers winning the earliest majors
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
       <a href="#cite_note-312">
        [312]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are many other famous
      <a href="/wiki/Golf_in_Scotland" title="Golf in Scotland">
       golf courses in Scotland
      </a>
      , including
      <a href="/wiki/Carnoustie_Golf_Links" title="Carnoustie Golf Links">
       Carnoustie
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gleneagles,_Scotland" title="Gleneagles, Scotland">
       Gleneagles
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muirfield_(Scotland)" title="Muirfield (Scotland)">
       Muirfield
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Troon" title="Royal Troon">
       Royal Troon
      </a>
      . Other distinctive features of the national sporting culture include the
      <a href="/wiki/Highland_games" title="Highland games">
       Highland games
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Curling" title="Curling">
       curling
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Shinty" title="Shinty">
       shinty
      </a>
      . In boxing, Scotland has had 13 world champions, including
      <a href="/wiki/Ken_Buchanan" title="Ken Buchanan">
       Ken Buchanan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Benny_Lynch" title="Benny Lynch">
       Benny Lynch
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Jim_Watt_(boxer)" title="Jim Watt (boxer)">
       Jim Watt
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Scotland has competed at every Commonwealth Games since 1930 and has won 356 medals in total—91 Gold, 104 Silver and 161 Bronze.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
       <a href="#cite_note-313">
        [313]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Edinburgh played host to the Commonwealth Games in
      <a href="/wiki/1970_British_Commonwealth_Games" title="1970 British Commonwealth Games">
       1970
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/1986_Commonwealth_Games" title="1986 Commonwealth Games">
       1986
      </a>
      , and most recently
      <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">
       Glasgow
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/2014_Commonwealth_Games" title="2014 Commonwealth Games">
       2014
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
       <a href="#cite_note-314">
        [314]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
       Infrastructure
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">
       Transport
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Scotland" title="Transport in Scotland">
       Transport in Scotland
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="640" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg/220px-Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg/330px-Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg/440px-Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Road_to_Fort_William_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1804287.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Bilingual (
        <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">
         Gaelic
        </a>
        /
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_Language" title="English Language">
         English
        </a>
        ) roadsigns are found throughout the
        <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">
         Highlands
        </a>
        and the
        <a href="/wiki/Hebrides" title="Hebrides">
         Hebrides
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Road">
       Road
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The Scottish motorways and major
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trunk_roads" title="Trunk roads">
       trunk roads
      </a>
      are managed by
      <a href="/wiki/Transport_Scotland" title="Transport Scotland">
       Transport Scotland
      </a>
      . The remainder of the road network is managed by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_local_authorities" title="Scottish local authorities">
       Scottish local authorities
      </a>
      in each of their areas.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Air">
       Air
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Scotland has five main international airports (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Glasgow_International_Airport" title="Glasgow International Airport">
       Glasgow
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Airport" title="Edinburgh Airport">
       Edinburgh
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen_Airport" title="Aberdeen Airport">
       Aberdeen
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Glasgow_Prestwick_Airport" title="Glasgow Prestwick Airport">
       Glasgow Prestwick
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Inverness_Airport" title="Inverness Airport">
       Inverness
      </a>
      ), which together serve 150 international destinations with a wide variety of scheduled and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chartered_flights" title="Chartered flights">
       chartered flights
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
       <a href="#cite_note-315">
        [315]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Global_Infrastructure_Partners" title="Global Infrastructure Partners">
       GIP
      </a>
      operates Edinburgh airport and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Airports_Authority" title="British Airports Authority">
       BAA
      </a>
      operates (Aberdeen and Glasgow International), while
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Highlands_and_Islands_Airports_Limited" title="Highlands and Islands Airports Limited">
       Highland and Islands Airports
      </a>
      operates 11 regional airports, including Inverness, which serve the more remote locations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HIAL_316-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-HIAL-316">
        [316]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">
       Scottish Government
      </a>
      owns Glasgow Prestwick, having purchased the airport from
      <a href="/wiki/Infratil" title="Infratil">
       Infratil
      </a>
      for a nominal sum.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
       <a href="#cite_note-317">
        [317]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">
       Rail
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="910" data-file-width="1366" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG/220px-Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG/330px-Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG/440px-Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Haymarket_-_DRS_68007_evening_commuter_service.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Domestic rail services are operated by
        <a href="/wiki/Abellio_ScotRail" title="Abellio ScotRail">
         Abellio ScotRail
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Network_Rail" title="Network Rail">
       Network Rail Infrastructure Limited
      </a>
      owns and operates the fixed infrastructure assets of the railway system in Scotland, while the Scottish Government retains overall responsibility for rail strategy and funding in Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Office_of_Rail_Regulation_318-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Office_of_Rail_Regulation-318">
        [318]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland's rail network has around 340 railway stations and 3,000 kilometres (1,900 mi) of track. Over 62 million passenger journeys are made each year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
       <a href="#cite_note-319">
        [319]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_Main_Line" title="East Coast Main Line">
       East Coast
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_Main_Line" title="West Coast Main Line">
       West Coast
      </a>
      main railway lines connect the major cities and towns of Scotland with each other and with the rail network in England.
      <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Trains_East_Coast" title="Virgin Trains East Coast">
       Virgin Trains
      </a>
      provides inter-city rail journeys between
      <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">
       Glasgow
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">
       Edinburgh
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen" title="Aberdeen">
       Aberdeen
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Inverness" title="Inverness">
       Inverness
      </a>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">
       London
      </a>
      . Domestic rail services within Scotland are operated by
      <a href="/wiki/Abellio_ScotRail" title="Abellio ScotRail">
       ScotRail
      </a>
      . During the time of
      <a href="/wiki/British_Rail" title="British Rail">
       British Rail
      </a>
      the West Coast Main Line from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Euston" title="London Euston">
       London Euston
      </a>
      to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Glasgow_Central_railway_station" title="Glasgow Central railway station">
       Glasgow Central
      </a>
      was electrified in the early 1970s, followed by the East Coast Main Line in the late 1980s. British Rail created the
      <a href="/wiki/ScotRail_(brand)" title="ScotRail (brand)">
       ScotRail brand
      </a>
      . When British Rail existed, many railway lines in Strathclyde were electrified. Strathclyde Passenger Transport Executive was at the forefront with the acclaimed "largest electrified rail network outside London". Some parts of the network are electrified, but there are no electrified lines in the Highlands, Angus, Aberdeenshire, the cities of Dundee or Aberdeen, or Perth &amp; Kinross, and none of the islands has a rail link (although the railheads at
      <a href="/wiki/Kyle_of_Lochalsh" title="Kyle of Lochalsh">
       Kyle of Lochalsh
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mallaig" title="Mallaig">
       Mallaig
      </a>
      principally serve the islands).
     </p>
     <p>
      The East Coast Main Line crosses the
      <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Forth" title="Firth of Forth">
       Firth of Forth
      </a>
      by the
      <a href="/wiki/Forth_Bridge" title="Forth Bridge">
       Forth Bridge
      </a>
      . Completed in 1890, this
      <a href="/wiki/Cantilever_bridge" title="Cantilever bridge">
       cantilever bridge
      </a>
      has been described as "the one internationally recognised Scottish landmark".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
       <a href="#cite_note-320">
        [320]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scotland's rail network is managed by Transport Scotland.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TRANSSCOT_321-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TRANSSCOT-321">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Water">
       Water
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg/220px-Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg/330px-Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg/440px-Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Isle_of_Mull_at_Greenock_-_geograph.org.uk_-_621136.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caledonian_McBrayne" title="Caledonian McBrayne">
         <i>
          Calmac
         </i>
        </a>
        ferry at
        <a href="/wiki/Greenock" title="Greenock">
         Greenock
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Regular ferry services operate between the Scottish mainland and outlying islands. Ferries serving both the inner and outer
      <a href="/wiki/Hebrides" title="Hebrides">
       Hebrides
      </a>
      are principally operated by the
      <a href="/wiki/State-owned_enterprise" title="State-owned enterprise">
       State-owned enterprise
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Caledonian_MacBrayne" title="Caledonian MacBrayne">
       Caledonian MacBrayne
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Services to the
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Isles" title="Northern Isles">
       Northern Isles
      </a>
      are operated by
      <a href="/wiki/Serco" title="Serco">
       Serco
      </a>
      . Other routes, served by multiple companies, connect southwest Scotland to
      <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">
       Northern Ireland
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/DFDS_Seaways" title="DFDS Seaways">
       DFDS Seaways
      </a>
      operate a freight-only service from
      <a href="/wiki/Rosyth" title="Rosyth">
       Rosyth
      </a>
      , near Edinburgh, to
      <a href="/wiki/Zeebrugge" title="Zeebrugge">
       Zeebrugge
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">
       Belgium
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Additional routes are operated by local authorities.
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>

       <li id="cite_note-1707_protests-19">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-1707_protests_19-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation book">
          Devine, T. M. (1999).
          <i>
           The Scottish Nation 1700–2000
          </i>
          . Penguin Books. p. 9.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-14-023004-1" title="Special:BookSources/0-14-023004-1">
           0-14-023004-1
          </a>
          .
          <q>
           From that point on anti-union demonstrations were common in the capital. In November rioting spread to the south west, that stronghold of strict Calvinism and covenanting tradition. The Glasgow mob rose against union sympathisers in disturbances that lasted intermittently for over a month
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.aufirst=T.+M.&amp;rft.aulast=Devine&amp;rft.btitle=The+Scottish+Nation+1700%932000&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=0-14-023004-1&amp;rft.pages=9&amp;rft.pub=Penguin+Books&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-20">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-20">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080101193416/http://www.parliament.uk/actofunion/06_03_mob.html" rel="nofollow">
           "Act of Union 1707 Mob unrest and disorder"
          </a>
          . London: The House of Lords. 2007. Archived from
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.parliament.uk/actofunion/06_03_mob.html" rel="nofollow">
           the original
          </a>
          on 1 January 2008
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            23 December
           </span>
           2007
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.btitle=Act+of+Union+1707+Mob+unrest+and+disorder&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.parliament.uk%2Factofunion%2F06_03_mob.html&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pub=The+House+of+Lords&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-21">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-21">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">

          . Scottish Parliament

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.btitle=Opening+of+Parliament%3A+Procession+of+the+Crown+of+Scotland&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.parliament.scot%2Fnewsandmediacentre%2F100237.aspx&amp;rft.pub=Scottish+Parliament&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-22">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-22">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Collier, J. G. (2001)
         <a class="external text" href="http://assets.cambridge.org/052178/2600/sample/0521782600ws.pdf" rel="nofollow">
          <i>
           Conflict of Laws (Third edition)
          </i>
         </a>
         (pdf)
         <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">
          Cambridge University Press
         </a>
         . "For the purposes of the English
         <a href="/wiki/Conflict_of_laws" title="Conflict of laws">
          conflict of laws
         </a>
         , every country in the world which is not part of
         <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">
          England and Wales
         </a>
         is a foreign country and its foreign laws. This means that not only totally foreign independent countries such as France or Russia ... are foreign countries but also
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Colonies" title="British Colonies">
          British Colonies
         </a>
         such as the
         <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">
          Falkland Islands
         </a>
         . Moreover, the other parts of the United Kingdom – Scotland and Northern Ireland – are foreign countries for present purposes, as are the other
         <a href="/wiki/British_Islands" title="British Islands">
          British Islands
         </a>
         , the
         <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">
          Isle of Man
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Jersey" title="Jersey">
          Jersey
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Guernsey" title="Guernsey">
          Guernsey
         </a>
         ."
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-administrative_control-23">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-administrative_control_23-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Devine, T. M. (1999),
         <i>
          The Scottish Nation 1700–2000
         </i>
         , P.288–289,
         <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0140230041">
          ISBN 0-14-023004-1
         </a>
         <i>
          "created a new and powerful
         </i>
         local state
         <i>
          run by the Scottish bourgeoisie and reflecting their political and religious values. It was this local state, rather than a distant and usually indifferent Westminster authority, that in effect routinely governed Scotland"
         </i>
        </span>
       </li>

       <li id="cite_note-35">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-35">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The earliest known evidence is a flint arrowhead from
         <a href="/wiki/Islay" title="Islay">
          Islay
         </a>
         . See Moffat, Alistair (2005)
         <i>
          Before Scotland: The Story of Scotland Before History
         </i>
         . London. Thames &amp; Hudson. Page 42.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-36">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-36">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Sites at
         <a href="/wiki/Cramond" title="Cramond">
          Cramond
         </a>
         dated to 8500 BC and near
         <a href="/wiki/Kinloch_Castle" title="Kinloch Castle">
          Kinloch
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B9m" title="Rùm">
          Rùm
         </a>
         from 7700 BC provide the earliest known evidence of human
         <u>
          occupation
         </u>
         in Scotland. See
         <a class="external text" href="http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=2146410357" rel="nofollow">
          "The Megalithic Portal and Megalith Map: Rubbish dump reveals time-capsule of Scotland's earliest settlements"
         </a>
         megalithic.co.uk. Retrieved 10 February 2008 and Edwards, Kevin J. and Whittington, Graeme "Vegetation Change" in Edwards, Kevin J. &amp; Ralston, Ian B.M. (Eds) (2003)
         <i>
          Scotland After the Ice Age: Environment, Archaeology and History, 8000 BC–AD 1000
         </i>
         . Edinburgh.
         <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_University_Press" title="Edinburgh University Press">
          Edinburgh University Press
         </a>
         . Page 70.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-37">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-37">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation book">
          Pryor, Francis (2003).
          <i>
           Britain BC
          </i>
          . London: HarperPerennial. pp. 98–104 &amp; 246–250.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-00-712693-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-00-712693-4">
           978-0-00-712693-4
          </a>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.aufirst=Francis&amp;rft.aulast=Pryor&amp;rft.btitle=Britain+BC&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-00-712693-4&amp;rft.pages=98-104+%26+246-250&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pub=HarperPerennial&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

        </span>

        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-72">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation book">
          Ross, David (2002).
          <i>
           Chronology of Scottish History
          </i>
          . Geddes &amp; Grosset. p. 56.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-85534-380-0" title="Special:BookSources/1-85534-380-0">
           1-85534-380-0
          </a>
          .
          <q>
           <b>
            1603:
           </b>
           James VI becomes
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_I_of_England" title="James I of England">
            James I of England
           </a>
           in the
           <a href="/wiki/Union_of_the_Crowns" title="Union of the Crowns">
            Union of the Crowns
           </a>
           , and leaves Edinburgh for London
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.aulast=Ross&amp;rft.btitle=Chronology+of+Scottish+History&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=1-85534-380-0&amp;rft.pages=56&amp;rft.pub=Geddes+%26+Grosset&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

        <span class="reference-text">

         , Winter 1990, vol. 30 (1), pp. 47–78.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-Rayner-Canham2008-108">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-Rayner-Canham2008_108-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         M. F. Rayner-Canham and G. Rayner-Canham,
         <i>
          Chemistry was Their Life: Pioneering British Women Chemists, 1880–1949
         </i>
         , (Imperial College Press, 2008), p. 264.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-109">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-109">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Richard J. Finlay,
         <i>
          Modern Scotland 1914–2000
         </i>
         (2006), pp 1–33
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-110">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-110">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         R. A. Houston and W.W. J. Knox, eds.
         <i>
          The New Penguin History of Scotland
         </i>
         (2001) p 426.
         <a class="external autonumber" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=VI5nAAAAMAAJ&amp;q=casualties" rel="nofollow">
          [1]
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Niall_Ferguson" title="Niall Ferguson">
          Niall Ferguson
         </a>
         points out in "The Pity of War" that the proportion of enlisted Scots who died was third highest in the war behind Serbia and Turkey and a much higher proportion than in other parts of the UK.
         <a class="external autonumber" href="https://books.google.com/books?ei=AJtPTtinKseKhQfUufnzBg&amp;ct=result&amp;id=QrYhAQAAIAAJ&amp;dq=niall+ferguson&amp;q=enlisted" rel="nofollow">
          [2]
         </a>
         <a class="external autonumber" href="http://news.scotsman.com/worldwarone/39Savage-Scots39-wish-you-weren39t.6487746.jp" rel="nofollow">
          [3]
         </a>
        </span>

         <i>
          The Companion Guide to the West Highlands of Scotland
         </i>
         . London. Collins.
         <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0002111357">
          ISBN 0-00-211135-7
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-138">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-138">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Johnstone, Scott
         <i>
          et al.
         </i>
         (1990)
         <i>
          The Corbetts and Other Scottish Hills
         </i>
         . Edinburgh. Scottish Mountaineering Trust. Page 9.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-139">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-139">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20101202071307/http://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/features/understanding/uk_records.shtml" rel="nofollow">
           "BBC Weather: UK Records"
          </a>
          . BBC.co.uk. Archived from
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/features/understanding/uk_records.shtml" rel="nofollow">
           the original
          </a>
          on 2 December 2010
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            21 September
           </span>
           2007
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.btitle=BBC+Weather%3A+UK+Records&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.co.uk%2Fweather%2Ffeatures%2Funderstanding%2Fuk_records.shtml&amp;rft.pub=BBC.co.uk.&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         The same temperature was also recorded in Braemar on 10 January 1982 and at
         <a href="/wiki/Altnaharra" title="Altnaharra">
          Altnaharra
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Highland_(council_area)" title="Highland (council area)">
          Highland
         </a>
         , on 30 December 1995.
        </span>
       </li>

         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.scotlandscensus.gov.uk/ods-analyser/jsf/tableView/crosstabTableView.xhtml" rel="nofollow">
           "Scotland's Census 2011 - National Records of Scotland Table KS201SC - Ethnic group - Release 3A"
          </a>
          . National Records for Scotland. 2014-02-27
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2014-02-27
           </span>
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.btitle=Scotland%27s+Census+2011+-+National+Records+of+Scotland+Table+KS201SC+-+Ethnic+group+-+Release+3A&amp;rft.date=2014-02-27&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.scotlandscensus.gov.uk%2Fods-analyser%2Fjsf%2FtableView%2FcrosstabTableView.xhtml&amp;rft.pub=National+Records+for+Scotland&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

          </span>
         </span>

       <li id="cite_note-178">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-178">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The
         <a class="external text" href="http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/QTTable?_bm=y&amp;-geo_id=01000US&amp;-qr_name=DEC_2000_SF3_U_QTP13&amp;-ds_name=DEC_2000_SF3_U&amp;-_lang=en&amp;-redoLog=false&amp;-_sse=on" rel="nofollow">
          US Census 2000
         </a>
         . The
         <a class="external autonumber" href="http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/ADPTable?_bm=y&amp;-geo_id=01000US&amp;-qr_name=ACS_2004_EST_G00_DP2&amp;-ds_name=ACS_2004_EST_G00_&amp;-_lang=en&amp;-_sse=on" rel="nofollow">
          [4]
         </a>
         American Community Survey 2004 by the US Census Bureau estimates 5,752,571 people claiming Scottish ancestry and 5,323,888 people claiming
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulster-Scots" title="Ulster-Scots">
          Scotch-Irish
         </a>
         ancestry.
         <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120108032342/http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/QTTable?_bm=y&amp;-geo_id=01000US&amp;-qr_name=DEC_2000_SF3_U_QTP13&amp;-ds_name=DEC_2000_SF3_U&amp;-_lang=en&amp;-redoLog=false&amp;-_sse=on" rel="nofollow">
          Archived
         </a>
         8 January 2012 at the
         <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">
          Wayback Machine
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </li>

          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.thecourier.co.uk/news/scotland-s-population-reaches-record-of-high-of-5-25-million-1.57049" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          . The Courier. 3 August 2012

           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         "Law and institutions, Gaelic" &amp; "Law and lawyers" in M. Lynch (ed.),
         <i>
          The Oxford Companion to Scottish History
         </i>
         , (Oxford, 2001), pp. 381–382 &amp; 382–386. Udal Law remains relevant to land law in Orkney and Shetland:
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070925220347/http://www.lawscot.org.uk/uploads/Ad-Hoc/AGeneralHistoryofScotsLaw_20thCentury.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           "A General History of Scots Law (20th century)"
          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          . Law Society of Scotland. Archived from
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.lawscot.org.uk/uploads/Ad-Hoc/AGeneralHistoryofScotsLaw_20thCentury.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           the original
          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          on 25 September 2007
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            20 September
           </span>
           2007
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.btitle=A+General+History+of+Scots+Law+%2820th+century%29&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lawscot.org.uk%2Fuploads%2FAd-Hoc%2FAGeneralHistoryofScotsLaw_20thCentury.pdf&amp;rft.pub=Law+Society+of+Scotland&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">

          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.btitle=Celtic+geographies%3A+old+culture%2C+new+times&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3D02kVSmK8EwMC%26pg%3DPA142%26dq%3DScotland%2BCeltic%2Bnation%26cd%3D4&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-22396-6&amp;rft.pages=142&amp;rft.place=Stroud%2C+Gloucestershire&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-Newspapers-301">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-Newspapers_301-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-Newspapers_301-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://archive.ifla.org/IV/ifla68/papers/051-127e.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           "Newspapers and National Identity in Scotland"
          </a>

           (PDF)

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">
       Further reading
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="refbegin columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
      <ul>
       <li>
        Devine, T. M. [1999] (2000).
        <i>
         The Scottish Nation 1700–2000
        </i>
        (New Ed. edition). London:Penguin.
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0140230041">
         ISBN 0-14-023004-1
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Donnachie, Ian and George Hewitt.
        <i>
         Dictionary of Scottish History.
        </i>
        (2001). 384 pp.
       </li>
       <li>
        Keay, John, and Julia Keay.
        <i>
         Collins Encyclopedia of Scotland
        </i>
        (2nd ed. 2001), 1101pp; 4000 articles; emphasis on history
       </li>
       <li>
        Koch, J. T.
        <i>
         Celtic Culture: a Historical Encyclopedia
        </i>
        (ABC-CLIO, 2006),
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1851094407">
         ISBN 1-85109-440-7
        </a>
        , 999pp
       </li>
       <li>
        Tabraham, Chris, and Colin Baxter.
        <i>
         The Illustrated History of Scotland
        </i>
        (2004)
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/1932573011/" rel="nofollow">
         excerpt and text search
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Trevor-Roper" title="Hugh Trevor-Roper">
         Trevor-Roper, Hugh
        </a>
        ,
        <i>
         The Invention of Scotland: Myth and History
        </i>
        , Yale, 2008,
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0300136862">
         ISBN 0-300-13686-2
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        Watson, Fiona,
        <i>
         Scotland; From Prehistory to the Present.
        </i>
        Tempus, 2003. 286 pp.
       </li>
       <li>
        Wilson, Neil.
        <i>
         Lonely Planet Scotland
        </i>
        (2013)
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.amazon.com/Lonely-Planet-Scotland-Travel-Guide-ebook/dp/B00BJENK4O/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1385052818&amp;sr=1-2" rel="nofollow">
         excerpt and text search
        </a>
       </li>

        <i>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Specialized_monographs">
       Specialized monographs
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="refbegin columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em;">
      <ul>
       <li>
        Brown, Dauvit, (1999)
        <i>
         Anglo-French acculturation and the Irish element in Scottish Identity
        </i>
        in Smith, Brendan (ed.),
        <i>
         Insular Responses to Medieval European Change
        </i>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">
         Cambridge University Press
        </a>
        , pp. 135–53
       </li>
       <li>
        Brown, Michael (2004)
        <i>
         The Wars of Scotland, 1214–1371
        </i>
        , Edinburgh University Press., pp. 157–254
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation book">
         Dumville, David N. (2001). "St Cathróe of Metz and the Hagiography of Exoticism".
         <i>
          Irish Hagiography: Saints and Scholars
         </i>
         . Dublin: Four Courts Press. pp. 172–176.
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
          ISBN
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-85182-486-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-85182-486-1">
          978-1-85182-486-1
         </a>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.atitle=St+Cathr%C3%B3e+of+Metz+and+the+Hagiography+of+Exoticism&amp;rft.aufirst=David+N.&amp;rft.aulast=Dumville&amp;rft.btitle=Irish+Hagiography%3A+Saints+and+Scholars&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85182-486-1&amp;rft.pages=172-176&amp;rft.place=Dublin&amp;rft.pub=Four+Courts+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/George_T._Flom" title="George T. Flom">
         Flom, George Tobias
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         Scandinavian influence on Southern Lowland Scotch. A Contribution to the Study of the Linguistic Relations of English and Scandinavian
        </i>
        (
        <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University_Press" title="Columbia University Press">
         Columbia University Press
        </a>
        , New York. 1900)
       </li>
       <li>
        <cite class="citation book">
         Herbert, Maire (2000). "Rí Érenn, Rí Alban, kingship and identity in the ninth and tenth centuries". In Simon Taylor (ed.).
         <i>
          Kings, Clerics and Chronicles in Scotland, 500–1297
         </i>
         . Dublin: Four Courts Press. pp. 63–72.
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
          ISBN
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-85182-516-9" title="Special:BookSources/1-85182-516-9">
          1-85182-516-9
         </a>
         .
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AScotland&amp;rft.atitle=R%C3+%C3%89renn%2C+R%C3+Alban%2C+kingship+and+identity+in+the+ninth+and+tenth+centuries&amp;rft.aufirst=Maire&amp;rft.aulast=Herbert&amp;rft.btitle=Kings%2C+Clerics+and+Chronicles+in+Scotland%2C+500%931297&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.isbn=1-85182-516-9&amp;rft.pages=63-72&amp;rft.place=Dublin&amp;rft.pub=Four+Courts+Press&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
         <span style="display:none;">
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        MacLeod, Wilson (2004)
        <i>
         Divided Gaels: Gaelic Cultural Identities in Scotland and Ireland: c.1200–1650
        </i>
        .
        <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">
         Oxford University Press
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Pope, Robert (ed.),
        <i>
         Religion and National Identity: Wales and Scotland, c.1700–2000
        </i>
        (
        <a href="/wiki/University_of_Wales_Press" title="University of Wales Press">
         University of Wales Press
        </a>
        , 2001)
       </li>
       <li>
        Sharp, L. W.
        <i>
         The Expansion of the English Language in Scotland
        </i>
        , (Cambridge University PhD thesis, 1927), pp. 102–325;
       </li>
      </ul>
     </div>

     <ul>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.visitscotland.com/" rel="nofollow">
        Visit Scotland
       </a>
       , official site of Scotland's national tourist board.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://maps.nls.uk/" rel="nofollow">
        Maps
       </a>
       and
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.nls.uk/digitallibrary/index.html" rel="nofollow">
        digital collections
       </a>
       at the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Scotland" title="National Library of Scotland">
        National Library of Scotland
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.nas.gov.uk/" rel="nofollow">
        National Archives of Scotland
       </a>
       , official site of the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Archives_of_Scotland" title="National Archives of Scotland">
        National Archives of Scotland
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="https://www.dmoz.org/Regional/Europe/United_Kingdom/Scotland" rel="nofollow">
        Scotland
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/DMOZ" title="DMOZ">
        DMOZ
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.scrol.gov.uk/" rel="nofollow">
        Scottish Census Results On Line
       </a>
       , official government site for Scotland's census results.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.gov.scot/Topics/Economy/Statistics" rel="nofollow">
        Scottish economic statistics
       </a>
       from the Scottish Government.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.gov.scot/" rel="nofollow">
        Scottish Government
       </a>
       , official site of the
       <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">
        Scottish Government
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.scotland.org/" rel="nofollow">
        Scotland.org
       </a>
       , the official online gateway to Scotland managed by the Scottish Government.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/" rel="nofollow">
        Scottish Parliament
       </a>
       , official site of the
       <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">
        Scottish Parliament
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.scotlandspeople.gov.uk/" rel="nofollow">
        ScotlandsPeople
       </a>
       , official government resource for Scottish
       <a href="/wiki/Genealogy" title="Genealogy">
        genealogy
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://statistics.gov.scot/" rel="nofollow">
        statistics.gov.scot
       </a>
       , open access to a range of official statistics about Scotland including small area statistics.
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.scottish-places.info/" rel="nofollow">
        Gazetteer for Scotland
       </a>
       , an extensive guide to the places and people of Scotland by the
       <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scottish_Geographical_Society" title="Royal Scottish Geographical Society">
        Royal Scottish Geographical Society
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/University_of_Edinburgh" title="University of Edinburgh">
        University of Edinburgh
       </a>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.streetsofscotland.co.uk/" rel="nofollow">
        Streets of Scotland
       </a>
       , photos from Scotland's streets.
      </li>
      <li>
       <img alt="" data-file-height="256" data-file-width="256" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/16px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/24px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Openstreetmap_logo.svg/32px-Openstreetmap_logo.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
       Geographic data related to
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.openstreetmap.org/browse/relation/58446" rel="nofollow">
        Scotland
       </a>
       at
       <a href="/wiki/OpenStreetMap" title="OpenStreetMap">
        OpenStreetMap
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>

                      <td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
                       <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
                        <ul>
                         <li>
                          <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_actors" title="List of Scottish actors">
                           Actors
                          </a>
                         </li>
                         <li>
                          <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_artists" title="List of Scottish artists">
                           Artists
                          </a>
                         </li>
                         <li>
                          <a href="/wiki/Scottish_inventions_and_discoveries" title="Scottish inventions and discoveries">
                           Inventors
                          </a>
                         </li>
                         <li>
                          <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_musicians" title="List of Scottish musicians">
                           Musicians
                          </a>
                         </li>
                         <li>
                          <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_scientists" title="List of Scottish scientists">
                           Scientists
                          </a>
                         </li>
                         <li>
                          <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_writers" title="List of Scottish writers">
                           Writers
                          </a>
                         </li>
                        </ul>
                       </div>
                      </td>
                     </tr>
                    </table>
                   </td>
                  </tr>

                   </td>

                <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

                    <img alt="Isle of Man" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="600" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Man.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Man.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Man.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Man.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Man.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Isle_of_Man.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                   </a>
                  </span>
                  <a href="/wiki/Allan_Bell" title="Allan Bell">
                   Bell
                  </a>
                 </span>
                </li>
               </ul>
              </div>
             </td>
            </tr>
           </table>
          </div>

       <tr>
        <th class="navbox-group" scope="row">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:Authority_control" title="Help:Authority control">
          Authority control
         </a>
        </th>
        <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">
         <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span style="white-space:nowrap;">
             <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/identities/containsVIAFID/258766271" rel="nofollow">
              WorldCat Identities
             </a>
            </span>
           </li>
           <li>
            <span style="white-space:nowrap;">
             <a href="/wiki/Virtual_International_Authority_File" title="Virtual International Authority File">
              VIAF
             </a>
             :
             <span class="uid">
              <a class="external text" href="https://viaf.org/viaf/258766271" rel="nofollow">
               258766271
              </a>
             </span>
            </span>
           </li>
           <li>
            <span style="white-space:nowrap;">
             <a href="/wiki/Integrated_Authority_File" title="Integrated Authority File">
              GND
             </a>
             :
             <span class="uid">
              <a class="external text" href="http://d-nb.info/gnd/4053233-1" rel="nofollow">
               4053233-1
              </a>
             </span>
            </span>
           </li>
           <li>
